dict.string: An immunoglobulins test is done to measure the level of immunoglobulins, also known as antibodies, in your blood. Antibodies are substances made by the body's immune system in response to bacteria, viruses, fungus, animal dander, or cancer cells. Antibodies attach to the foreign substances so the immune system can destroy them.

21- Hydroxylase Antibody is a marker adrenal insufficiency that may cause Addison's disease. This test is used to help diagnose and monitor patients suspected to have autoimmune adrenocortical insufficiency (the autoimmune form of Addison's disease).
Aids in the detection of those at risk of developing autoimmune adrenal failure or Addisons disease.
Addison disease, polyglandular syndrome and autoimmune adrenal insufficiency.

Anticardiolipin Antibody (aCL) is a form of the anti-mitochondrial antibody and part of the antiphospholipid family (which is the main constituent of the cell membrane) that's directed against cardiolipin, which is found in the diseases such as Systemic Lupus Erythematous (SLE). aCL testing is usually done when there's excessive clotting in the presence of 1) Vascular thombotic episodes of tissues or organ systems, or 2) Unexplained pregnancy loss of a fetus.
Help diagnose conditions such as Sjögren’s syndrome, connective tissue disease and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
Systemic Lupus Erythematous (SLE), Syphilis, Thrombocytopenia Infection, Drugs such as PCN, quinidine, dilantin, and hydralazine.

AIDS, inflammation, autoimmune diseases, or cancer. Syphilis can cause a false- positive. Medications such as chlorpromazine, hydralazine, penicillin, phenytoin, procainamide, and quinidine can cause a false-positive result.

Anticentromere Antibodies a.k.a. "centromere antibody" are antibodies that go against the centromeres, and with its high sensitivity, it's used to help diagnose systemic cutaneous scleroderma. The anticentromere antibody is usually found in autoimmune disorders and is also checked when a patient tests (+) for Antinuclear Antibody (ANA). The ACA can also predict portal hypertension in the presence of biliary cirrhosis.
Useful to help diagnose those with signs/symptoms linked with connective tissue diseases.

AMA are comprised of immunoglobulins that form against the mitocondria in liver tissue. Approximately 95 – 98% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis will have auto antibodies in their blood, which react with the inner lining of the mitochondria. These antibodies are what we call the Antimitochondrial Antibody (AMA).
Establishing the diagnosis of primary biliary cirrhosis.
Autoimmune Hepatitis, Chronic Active Hepatitis, Cholestatis, Extrahepatic obstruction, Primary Biliary Cirrhosis (PBC), SLE, Syphilis, Acute Infectious Hepatitis.

Myocardial Antibodies are autoantibodies (proteins that attack your own cells) that are specific to cardiac tissue - attacking a person's own cardiac cells, or myocardium. This test may be ordered in patients suspected of having various cardiomyopathies, especially idiopathic dilated cardiomyopahty, Dressler's Syndrome , rheumatic fever, and myocarditis.
Useful for evaluating patients suspected of having inflammatory cardiomyopathy, post-cardiotomy or post-myocardial infarction syndromes.
Cardiomyopathy, myocardial infarction, thoracotomy syndrome, rheumatic fever, rheumatic heart disease, Streptococcal infections.

The Anti-CCP Antibody test is a test that is extremely specific (more specific than the rheumatoid factor) to those who are suspected of having Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). This test can also predict the likelihood of a patient to acquire the autoimmune disease, Rheumatoid Arthritis before symptoms occur. Patients who have Rheumatoid Arthritis will produce antibodies against chains of citrullin amino acids which is called the Anti-Cyclic Citrulinated Peptide Antibody (Anti-CCP).
Useful for evaluating patients suspected of having rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiating RA from other connective tissue diseases that may mimic arthritis.

Characterized as and autoantibody and one of two types of an antinuclear subtype of the anti-DNA antibodies, this antibody is useful to help diagnose Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), know to attacking the bodys own cells. This anybody is detectable in approximately 65 - 98% of these patients. Those patients with this antibody often, unfortunately, succumb to lupus nephritis.
Useful for evaluating patients suspected of having signs and symptoms consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and monitoring the disease progression.
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic hepatitis, biliary cirrhosis, infectious mononucleosis, rheumatoid arthritis.
Medications such as hydralazine and procainamide could cause increased levels.

The Glomerular Basement Membrane Antibody (Anti-GBM) is used to evaluate patients with acute renal failure or pulmonary hemorrhage. These antibodies tend to destroy capillaries in the lungs or the kidneys (called the glomerular basement). It can also be used to diagnose Goodpasture's syndrome in 87% of patients. Antibodies to the glomerular basement can destroy renal and pulmonary tissue causing glomerulonephritis, hemorrhagic pneumonitis which can ultimately result in death.
Useful to help diagnose Goodpasture syndrome and to evaluate patients with renal failure or pulmonary hemorrhage.
Goodpasture's syndrome, autoimmune glomerulonephritis, lupus Nephritis

Anti-SS-A is considered a antinuclear antibody that is used to help diagnosed Sjogrens syndrome (which is an immunogenic disease that destroys the lacrimal and salivary exocrine glands which lead to dryness in the conjunctiva and mucosa).This anybody is found in approximately 60 to 70% of patients with Sjogren's syndrome. When this anybody along with SS–B are found in conjunction, and particularly when the ANA is negative, it's highly suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome. Patients with SS-A may also have antibodies to cardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, and clinical thromboses. This has been termed antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.
Help diagnose conditions such as Sjögren’s syndrome, connective tissue disease and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
Positive findings may be suggestive of Sjogrens syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, neonatal lupus, ANA – negative SLE.

Considered a anti-nuclear anybody that is used to help diagnosed Sjogrens syndrome (an immunogenic disease that destroys the lacrimal and salivary exocrine glands which lead to dryness in the conjunctiva and mucosa). When this anybody along with SS–A are found together that is highly suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome.
Help diagnose conditions such as Sjögren’s syndrome, connective tissue disease and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
Positive findings may be suggestive of Sjogrens syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, neonatal lupus, ANA – negative SLE.

Traditionally, parietal cell antibodies are present in about 80% of patients with pernicious anemia and are rarely present in gastric ulcer, gastric cancer, or in association with antinuclear antibodies. These antibodies insult the parietal cells that exist in the proximal stomach and reproduce hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor. Intrinsic factor is paramount for that intake of vitamin B12. 90% of these patients that present with this antibody are highly suspicious for pernicious anemia.
Useful to help diagnose patients with immune-mediated vitamin B12 deficiency and pernicious anemia.
Increased levels suggestive of pernicious anemia, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, myxedema, juvenile diabetes, Addison's disease, atrophic gastritis.

Anti-smooth muscle antibodies are antibodies that attack the F-actin protein found in the smooth muscle, especially in the liver. Anti-SMA is used to help aid in the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis which appears approximately 70 to 80% of the patients with chronic active hepatitis (CAH). It can also be used to diagnose other liver diseases such as primary biliary cholangitis as well.
Useful to help diagnose patients suspected of having chronic liver disease in which chronic active autoimmune hepatitis is suspected.
Increased levels may be suggested of CAH, asthma, multiple sclerosis, cancer, intrinsic asthma, viral hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, mononucleosis hepatitis.

This is the antibiotic that is primary antinuclear use to diagnose scleroderma. Is usually present in approximately 45% of patients with the disease. The absence of the antibody does not suggest exclusion of scleroderma, however the higher the titer values the more likely the patient has scleroderma.
Used to help diagnose patients with scleroderma and other connective tissue diseases in whom the test for antinuclear antibodies is positive.
Positive values may be suggestive of scleroderma, crest syndrome. Drugs: penicillin, tetracycline, streptomycin, isoniazid, methyldopa, aminosalicylic acid.

Arterial Blood Gas testing measures the content of carbon dioxide, pH, and how much oxygen is present in the blood. This test is used to determine how well your lungs are able to exchange oxygen for carbon dioxide in the alveoli.

The Anion Gap is the difference in the measured cations and the measured anions in serum, plasma, or urine. The magnitude of this difference (i.e. gap) in the serum is often calculated in medicine when attempting to identify the cause of metabolic acidosis. If the gap is greater than normal, then high anion gap metabolic acidosis is diagnosed. A useful mnemonic to remember this is "MUDPILES" (Methanol, Uremia, Diabetic ketoacidosis, Propylene Glycol, Isoniazid, Lactic Acidosis, Ethylene Glycol, Salicylates).
Anion gap metabolic acidosis, aspirin, methanol, uremia, Diabetic ketoacidosis, paraldehyde, ischemia, Lactic acidosis, ethanol, the salicylates.

Hyperlipidemia could falsely decrease Anion Gap from the under measurement of Na+. Medications such as acetazolamide, lithium, spironolactone, and sulindac could also falsely decrease the AG.
Medications such as carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide because of the effect on bicarb), ethanol, methanol, and salicylates could falsely increae the Anion Gap.
Used to evaluate the presence of metabolic acidosis and electrolyte imbalances.

Base Excess represents the amount of buffering anions in the blood. With a constant temp of (37 C) and normal C02 of (40 mmHg), BE measures the amount of acid or base needed to titrate one liter of fully oxygenated blood to a pH of 7.40.
Negative base excess (deficit less than -2 mEq/L) indicates a metabolic acidosis (e.g., lactic acidosis).
A positive base excess (more than +2 mEq/L) suggests metabolic alkalosis or compensation to prolonged respiratory acidosis.
Used as an indicator of the metabolic component of acid-base disorders.

HCO3 is the most important buffer in the blood and prevents the blood from becoming too acidic. Most of the CO2 content in the blood is HCO3. The acidity is affected by foods or medications that we ingest, and the function of the kidneys and the lungs. Regulated by the kidneys, it's directly correlated with the pH (as pH increases, bicarb increases) and indirectly related to the C02 (as C02 increases, bicarb will decrease). The chemical notation for bicarbonate in most lab reports is HCO3 - or represented as the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) on a chemistry panel.
Respiratory acidosis, metabolic alkalosis, drugs, diuretics
Renal failure, salicylate toxicity, starvation, shock, metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis
Used to evaluate the presence of HC03 in acidosis/alkalosis. Monitor serum bicarbonate levels.

This measures how much carbon dioxide is dissolved in the blood and how well carbon dioxide is able to move out of the body. The CO2 level is related to the respiratory exchange of carbon dioxide in the lungs, and is part of the body's buffering system. Generally, when used with other electrolytes, it is a good indicator of acidosis and alkalinity.
Respiratory acidosis, Myasthenia Gravis, respiratory depressants, alcohol, benzodiazepines, Guillain-Barré syndrome.
Alcohol, airway obstruction, asthma, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, CHF, COPD, Guillain-Barré syndrome, Myasthenia gravis, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, VQ mismatching.
Used to evaluate respiratory disorders such as acidosis/alkalosis, respiratory failure, COPD, and apnea tests.
This measures the pressure of oxygen dissolved in the blood and how well oxygen is able to move from the airspace of the lungs into the blood.
Alcohol, anemia, polycythemia, V/Q mismatching i.e. (asthma, atelectasis, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism). Drugs: barbiturates, benzodiazepines, opioids.

Oxygen saturation is also referred to as SPO2. Oxygen saturation is a measure of how much oxygen in the blood is carrying as a percentage of the maximum he could carry. Basically, a saturation of 97% of the total amount of hemoglobin in the body is filled with oxygen molecules. A range of 96% to 100% is generally considered normal. Anything below 90% could quickly lead to life – threatening complications.

The pH measures hydrogen ions (H +) in the blood and is inversely proportional to the actual hydrogen ion concentration. Hence, as the hydrogen ion concentration decreases, the pH increases, and vice versa. The pH of blood is usually between 7.35 - 7.45. A pH of less than 7.0 is acidic, and a pH greater than 7.0 is called basic (alkaline), so blood is slightly basic. A normal physiological pH usually is around 7.4. After an ABG sample is taken, the sample must be transported on ice without exposure to air or the specimen could be contaminated.

Respiratory alkalosis (hyperventilation syndrome, inappropriate ventilator settings, liver diseases and sepsis). Metabolic alkalosis, bicarbonate administration, diuretics, volume depletion and vomiting.
Anion gap metabolic acidosis, Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis, Respiratory Acidosis.
Used to evaluate metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders.

The basic metabolic panel is one of the most common ordered lab panels ordered which provides information about the body's metabolism. It measures electrolytes, renal function, fluid balance and as well glucose levels.

Sodium is an important cation found mostly in the extracellular fluid determined primarily by the volume status of a patient. Sodium is important in regulating H2O distribution in the body, osmotic pressure, neuromuscular function, acid-base balance and electrolyte balance.
Cushing's syndrome, dehydration, diabetes insipidus/mellitus, excessive sweating, hypertonic saline.
Ace inhibitors, ATN, AIDS, adrenal insufficiency, CHF, Cirrhosis, diarrhea, hypothyroidism, nasogastric suctioning, SIADH.
Overall kidney function, abx, laxatives, steroids, diuretics, and diet.
Used to evaluate acid-base balance, water balance, water intoxication, and dehydration. Also used to monitor the effectiveness of medications such as diuretics.

Potassium is an important cation found mostly in the intracellular fluid that is responsible for a variety of different functions such as neuromuscular function, contraction of skeletal smooth and cardiac muscle. It also helps to maintain acid-base balance. K + greater than 7.0 can cause peaked T waves and ventricular dysrhythmias.
Acidosis, Addison's disease, Dehydration, infections, Renal failure (acute and chronic), Hemolysis, transfusions, Ace inhibitors, NSAIDs, spironolactone.
Alkalosis, ascites, burns, Cushing's syndrome, diarrhea, diuretics, Insulin, and vomiting.

Hemolysis, tourniquets, Drugs: abx, antineoplastic drugs, captopril, epinephrine, heparin, histamine, isoniazid, lithium, mannitol, potassium-sparing diuretics, potassium supplements, insulin, Kayexalate, and succinylcholine.

Used to evaluate electrolytes imbalances, patients receiving hemodialysis, muscle weakness, hepatic encephalopathy, cardiac arrhythmia and renal failure. K+ levels are also used to monitor conditions such as DKA and any intravenous therapy for fluid replacement. Monitor known or suspected acidosis, as potassium shifts from RBCs into the extracellular fluid in acidotic states.

Chloride is a type of electrolyte. It works with other electrolytes such as potassium, sodium, and carbon dioxide (CO2) to help keep the proper balance of the body's fluids and maintain the body's acid – base balance.
Diarrhea, dehydration, hyperparathyroidism, excessive saline, renal failure, respiratory acidosis.
Adrenal insufficiency, cushing's syndrome, DKA, gastric suctioning, SIADH, renal failure, bicarbonates, corticosteroids and diuretics

NaCl infusions can increase the chloride level. Drugs such as acetazolamide, ammonium chloride, androgens, cortisone preparations, estrogens, hydrochlorothiazide, and NSAIDS can increase Cl levels.
Cl levels may decrease in the presence of loop & thiazide diuretics, aldosterone, bicarbonates, corticosteroids, cortisone.

Used to evaluate electrolytes imbalances, and acid-base status- distinguishing between types of acidosis such as (hyperchloremic vs. anion gap), monitor effectiveness of medications that increase or decrease overall serum chloride levels.

The C02 is actually measured as bicarbonate on a BMP. The bicarbonate (or total CO2) is an ion that acts as a buffer against pH disturbances. Bicarb (HCO3) is primarily converted into CO2 in order to be excreted from the lungs. HCO3 is important in calculating the Anion gap in diagnosing potential respiratory or metabolic disorders.

Drugs: aldosterone, barbiturates, bicarbonates, hydrocortisone, loop diuretics, and steroids.
Drugs that may cause decreased levels include methicillin, furadantin, tetracycline, thiazide diuretics.
Used to evaluate acid-base status- decreased CO2 in compensated metabolic acidosis & respiratory alkalosis. Increased CO2 in compensated metabolic alkalosis & respiratory acidosis.
The BUN is a by-product of protein metabolism. Urea nitrogen is what forms when protein breaks down. The BUN is one measure of adequate renal function, but is not as specific as serum creatinine.
Burns, dehydration, G.I. bleeding, pre-renal azotemia, postrenal attractions, renal failure, shock, aminoglycosides.
Liver failure, infancy, nephrotic syndrome, hemodilution, starvation, malabsorbtion.

Pregnancy, protein intake, hydration status, GI bleeds.
Drugs that increase BUN: allopurinol, aminoglycosides, cephalosporins, chloral hydrate, cisplatin, nephrotoxic drugs, lasix, Indocin, methotrexate, methyldopa, propranolol, rifampin, spironolactone, tetracyclines, thiazide diuretics.
Drugs that decrease BUN: abx such as chloramphenicol and streptomycin.
Used to evaluate renal and liver function. Monitor hydration status and the effects of nephrotoxic and hepatotoxic medications.

Creatinine is a breakdown product of creatine, which is an essential part of the muscle. A measurement of the serum creatinine level in conjunction with the BUN is directly related to renal function. Thus, in cases where renal function is normal, serum creatinine will remain low. Conversely, when renal function is suboptimal, serum creatinine levels will rise.
Chronic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis, rhabdomyolysis, Diabetic nephropathy, Pyelonephritis, shock, dehydration, congestive heart failure, atherosclerosis.
Excessive fluid intake, muscular dystrophy, myasthenia gravis.
Drugs that can increase serum creatinine: ACE inhibitors, aminoglycosides, chemotherapy, and other nephrotoxic drugs, such as cephalosporins.
Used to evaluate renal function and the degree of nephron damage in known kidney disease. Monitor the effectiveness of nephrotoxic medications in the presence of renal disease.
A blood glucose test measures the amount of sugar called glucose in a sample of your blood. Glucose is a major source of energy for most cells in the body, including those in the brain.
Hyperglycemia can be indicative of diabetes mellitus (DM).

IV fluids with dextrose, pregnancy, anesthesia, stroke, myocardial infarction, shock, exercise, burns.
Drugs that may increase glucose: statins, corticosteroids, antidepressants (tricyclics), antipsychotics, beta blockers, diuretics, epinephrine, estrogens, isoniazid, lithium, niacin, phenothiazines, phenytoin, salicylates (acute toxicity), and gluca­gon.
Drugs decreased glucose include sulfonylureas, acetaminophen, alcohol, steroids, insulin, monoamine oxidase inhibitors.
Critical Values: > 4 Weeks: ≥ 400 or ≤ 50 mg/dL, < 4 Weeks: ≥ 400 or ≤ 40 mg/dL
Assists in diagnosing hypoglycemia, insulinoma, diabetes, and evaluate for disorders such as carbohydrate metabolism.

Cardiac enzymes are used to test the functioning of the heart and to determine whether someone is having, or did have a heart attack. Enzymes may be drawn 2- 3 times as it may take between 2 – 24 hours for different enzymes to be detectable in the blood stream.

B-Type Natriuretic Peptide is a hormone that is released from the ventricles in the heart in response to atrioventricular stretch and acts as a vasodilator. BNP is a classic marker for ventricular systolic dysfunction and an indicator of heart failure. As one of the three major natriuretic peptides: ANP, BNP, and CNP, BNP, in particular, corresponds to less intraocular pressures.
Acute Coronary Syndrome, Congestive Heart Failure, Coronary Artery Disease, Left Ventricular Dysfunction, Pulmonary embolism, Cor Pulmonale, systemic hypotension.
BNP can typically be elevated in patients post-op cardiac surgery, women, elderly. Also, drugs such as endogenous peptides will also increase the BNP.
Used to evaluate congestive heart failure (CHF).

Cardiac output (expressed in L/min) is the amount of blood that the heart pumps in one minute. CO is dependent on the heart rate, contractility, preload, and afterload. Evaluating these values can determine cardiac performance, and as well different types of shock.
Cardiogenic shock, hypovolemic shock, neurogenic shock.
Used to evaluate the effectiveness of the heart's ability to pump blood systemically.

Creatine Kinase-MB is an enzyme that's found in cardiac cells which is a subunit of creatine kinase. It's one of the three isoenzymes of CK, with the others being CK-MM (94–100%, skeletal muscle origin, and the heart), CK-MB (located mostly in the heart, but small amounts found in skeletal muscles), and CK-BB (Normal 0%, brain origin) brain injury (CVA, trauma), metastatic neoplasms (eg, prostate), malignant hyperthermia, colonic infarction. CK-MB usually increased 2 – 12 hrs post onset and peaks at 12-40 hrs., returns to normal in 24–72 h. CK-MB is still considered an acceptable test when troponin is not available considering that troponin is more specific. It should be noted that CK-MB can stay elevated for up to four days after myocardial infarctions and is less sensitive than other cardiac markers.
Cardiac trauma, cardiac surgery, myocardial infarction, polymyositis, carbon monoxide poisoning, crush injuries, pulmonary embolism, hypothyroidism, and muscular dystrophy.

Recent surgery, strenuous exercise. Intramuscular injections. Pregnancy may decrease levels. Drugs that could cause increased CPK levels: Ampicillin, anticoagulants, morphine, statins, lasix, lidocaine, succinylcholine, decadron.

Assists in diagnosing cardiac ischemia and acute myocardial infarctions, skeletal muscle disorders. Determine the benefit of coronary artery reperfusion after streptokinase administration or PCI, as evidenced by a decrease in CK-MB.

Creatine kinase is an enzyme used to detect rhabdomyolysis, cardiac inflammation or cardiac muscle damage. Considered less sensitive than troponin, and other cardiac markers, creatine kinase can increase 3 – 8 hours post onset, and peak at 24 hours. Post-myocardial infarction, enzyme levels can stay elevated up to 4 days.
AMI, myocarditis, muscular dystrophy, muscle trauma, stroke, defibrillation, cardiac catheterization, cardiac surgery, rhabdomyolysis, polymyositis, hypothyroidism, alcohol, rhabdomyolysis.

Recent surgery, strenuous exercise. Intramuscular injections. Pregnancy may decrease levels. Drugs that could cause increased CPK levels: ampicillin, anticoagulants, morphine, statins, lasix, lidocaine, succinylcholine, decadron.

Assists in diagnosing cardiac ischemia and acute myocardial infarctions, skeletal muscle disorders. Determine the benefit of coronary artery reperfusion after streptokinase administration or PCI, as evidenced by a decrease in CK-MB.

Ejection fraction is a test that is used to determine heart failure. By measuring how well the left and right ventricles of the heart are pumping, (most commonly by echocardiogram) this tests how much blood is pumped out of the ventricles during each contraction. Expressed as a % lower values can be indicative of heart failure. For example, an EF of 58 % means that 58 % of the blood in the LV is being pumped out each beat.

Ischemic cardiomyopathy, heart failure, cardiogenic shock. 55 - 70 % : Normal 40 - 54 %: Slightly below normal. Mild heart failure. 35 - 39 %: Moderately below the normal range. Mild heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction. < 35 %: Severely abnormal. Great risk for dysrhythmias, sudden cardiac death. Consider a VAD or heart transplant.
Used to evaluate ventricular size, regional wall motion, CAD, diagnose MI, ventricular aneurysms and valvular disease.

The heart rate is defined by the number of beats in one minute. Controlled by the primary pacemaker of the heart (SA node), the heart rate is a critical component of cardiac output. As cardiac output decreases, the heart rate will increase to compensate. The resting heart rate can vary during different phases of breathing, as a result of medications, and can vary in athletes as well as healthy individuals.
Exercise, pain, shock, use of chronotropes.
Medications such as beta blockers, increased vagal tone, cardiac failure.
Used to evaluate vagal stimulation, autonomic function sympathetic activity and sustaining arrhythmias.

The stroke volume is the amount of blood in mL's ejected from the LV. Typically, approximately two–thirds of the blood in the left ventricle is pumped out during one ventricular contraction. Coupled with the heart rate in a one minute cycle, we refer to this as the ventricular "stroke volume. (SV)" The SV is estimated by subtracting the end-diastolic volume (EDV) and the end-systolic volume (ESV). SV= EDV - ESV. The EDV simply the amount of blood filled in the LV prior to systole, and the ESV is the extra volume of blood remaining in the ventricle after systole. In a normal heart, the EDV is approx. 120 mL of blood and the ESV about 50 mL of blood. The difference in these two (EDV-ESV) is, 70 mL, which represents the SV. Therefore, any factor that alters either the EDV or the ESV will change SV. For example, an increase in EDV will overall improve the SV, whereas an increase in ESV will reduce the overall SV.
Used to evaluate fluid responsiveness, volume status, cardiac output and tissue perfusion.

Troponin is the most specific and sensitive cardiac marker for the detection of myocardial cell injury.
Troponin I is one of the three regulatory proteins that is distinguished from skeletal injury and is specific for myocardial infarction. Troponin is not typically detected in healthy people but tends to increase significantly after STEMI's as early as 2 to 3 hours after myocardial damage. Thus, troponins are particularly valuable when there is clinical suspicion of skeletal muscle injury or MI that may be below the detection limit for creatine phosphokinase (CK) and its MB isoenzyme (CK-MB).
Troponin levels that are greater than 0.4 ng/ mL should be concerning for myocardial infarction. It should be noted that troponins can stay elevated for several days after ST-elevation Myocardial Infarctions.
Myocardial infarction (AMI), cardiomyopathy, cardiothoracic surgery, thoracic trauma.
Troponins can be falsely elevated in those with severe muscle damage and dialysis patients.
Assists in diagnosing cardiac injury, cardiac ischemia and acute myocardial infarctions, myocardial cell damage.

Myoglobin is a protein that is found in heart & skeletal muscle tissue. When the muscles are damaged, myoglobin is released into the bloodstream and filtered by the kidneys. Large amounts of myoglobin can cause kidney damage.
Because myoglobin is found in both cardiac and skeletal muscle tissue, it has a low specificity for myocardial infarctions. Very high concentrations of myoglobin may increase the risk of acute renal failure. Because myoglobin is excreted in the urine and is nephrotoxic, urine output should frequently be monitored.
Myocardial infarction, skeletal muscle damage, rhabdomyolysis.
Intramuscular injections, recent administration of radioactive substances.
Used to evaluate skeletal muscle injury such as rhabdomyolysis & predicting a flare-up of polymyositis.

The clotting cascade is a very complicated process that involves numerous coagulation factors (active proenzymes) produced primarily by the liver. The coagulation study looks at the amount of the function of coagulation proteins that are circulating in the bloodstream which are essential for clot formation. People with bleeding disorders have a disruption in the clotting cascade. When the factors are low, it can cause clotting to fail which lead to unexplained bleeding.

The activated clotting time (ACT) is a test used at the bedside or in the OR used to document neutralization of high-dose unfractionated (standard) heparin therapy (especially after cardiac surgery, hemodialysis, and bypass). Factors that can affect the ACT is hemodilution, hypothermia, platelet function.
High-dose heparin during these procedures prevents clot formation but leaves the body in a fragile dynamic offset between clotting and bleeding. At this level of anticoagulation, the PTT is no longer clinically useful as a monitoring tool, so the ACT is used.
The ACT has several advantages over the PTT. 1) It's more accurate at higher doses of heparin therapy because the aPTT is not measurable at these ranges. 2) Can be performed at the bedside and is a less expensive test.
Heparin administration, some platelet disorders, severe clotting factor deficiency.
Clotted sample, heparin resistance, hypothermia, hemodiluted samples, platelet function.
Used to evaluate unexplained bleeding, preoperative testing monitoring anticoagulation therapy.

The D-Dimer is a fibrin split product (a small protein that's in the blood after a clot is degraded by fibrinolysis) used to evaluate suspected DVT and PE. Released when there's a fibrinolytic breakdown of fibrin.
Fibrinolysis is mediated by plasmin, which degrades fibrin clots into D-dimers and fibrin degradation products (FDP). Cancer patients often have positive D-dimers and FDP, usually representing low-grade, chronic DIC. Serial D-dimers may be used to monitor thromboembolisms.

DVT, PE, MI, CVA, aortic dissections, sickle cell crisis, cancer, renal failure, CHF, snake bites, life-threatening infections, liver disease, malignancy, inflammation, trauma, or a chronic hypercoagulable state.
Increased if the Rheumatoid factor (RF Factor) >50 IU/mL. Decreased in lipemic patients.
Useful for excluding the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis. Assists in diagnosing bleeding disorders such intravascular coagulation and DIC.

The INR is a calculation based on results of a PT that is used to monitor individuals who are being treated with the blood thinners; screens for abnormalities of coagulation factors involved in the extrinsic pathway. It's the standard to guide coumadin therapy and provides a more standardized measure against a standard reagent. It's a calculation that is used to adjust to the reagents that used during a prothrombin time test. Because the reagents in different laboratories may vary, the following formula is commonly used. INR = (PT of the patient/PT – control) ^ISI. ISI is the (International Sensitivity Index). INR is not affected by heparin.

Factor II, V, VII, X deficiencies, DIC, massive transfusions, liver disease, vitamin K deficiencies, coumadin, and fat malabsorption. Therapeutic INR is 2–3 for DVT, PE, TIAs, and atrial fibrillation. Mechanical heart valves require an INR of 2.5–3.5.

High-fat diets and alcohol may increase the PT.
Meds that increase include levels are allopurinol, aminosalicylic acid, barbiturates, beta-lactam antibiotics, cephalosporins, cholestyramine, chloral hydrate, cimetidine, clofibrate, colestipol, ethyl alcohol, glucagon, heparin, neomycin, oral anticoagulants, propylthiouracil, quinine, salicylates, and sulfonamides.
Meds that decreased levels are: anabolic steroids, barbiturates, digitalis, benadryl, estrogens, oral contraceptives, and vitamin K.

Used to evaluate factors II, V, VII, VIII, IX, and X. Prothrombin and vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, SLE. Monitor anticoagulation therapy. Assists in diagnosing bleeding disorders such intravascular coagulation and DIC.

The prothrombin time (PT) is a measure of the extrinsic pathways which include the following factors: II, V, VII, X; Used to monitor patients who are taking oral anticoagulants. When the PT is prolonged, it means that the blood is taking too long to clot. The PT is often compared to the PTT to determine which disorder may be present. For example:
PT- Prolonged & PTT - Normal: Liver disease, vitamin K deficiency, factor VII deficiency, early disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), coumadin therapy.
PT- Normal & PTT - Prolonged: Factor VIII, IX, XI deficiency, or XII, von Willebrand disease, autoantibodies against specific clotting factors (e.g., factor IX).
PT- Prolonged & PTT - Prolonged: Factor I, II, V or X deficiency, severe liver disease, DIC, coumadin overdose.
PT- Normal & PTT - Normal/ Slightly Prolonged: Further testing may be required to diagnose von Willebrand disease and other clotting factors because these values could also reflect normal hemostasis or mild coag deficiencies.
Factor II, V, VII, X deficiencies, DIC, massive transfusions, liver disease, vitamin K deficiencies, coumadin, and fat malabsorption.

High-fat diets and alcohol may increase the PT.
Meds that increase include levels are allopurinol, aminosalicylic acid, barbiturates, beta-lactam antibiotics, cephalosporins, cholestyramine, chloral hydrate, cimetidine, clofibrate, colestipol, ethyl alcohol, glucagon, heparin, neomycin, oral anticoagulants, propylthiouracil, quinine, salicylates, and sulfonamides.
Meds that decreased levels are: anabolic steroids, barbiturates, digitalis, benadryl, estrogens, oral contraceptives, and vitamin K.

Used to evaluate factors II, V, VII, VIII, IX, and X. Prothrombin and vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, SLE. Monitor anticoagulation therapy. Assists in diagnosing bleeding disorders such intravascular coagulation and DIC.

The Partial Thromboplastin Time, a.k.a the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a measure of the intrinsic clotting cascade, most often used to monitor heparin therapy. The intrinsic pathway measures the following factors: VIII, IX, XI, and XII.
Heparin therapy, hemophilia A and B, lupus - antiphospholipid antibody, vitamin K deficiency factors VII, and VIII deficiencies, von Willebrand disease, DIC, and anticoagulant drugs.
Hypercoagulable states, increased factor VII, inflammation, chronic illness, cancer.
Meds that can prolong the PTT are antihistamines, ascorbic acid, chlorpromazine, heparin, and salicylates.
Critical Values: PTT: > 100 sec, aPTT: > 70 sec
Assists in diagnosing diseases such as factor VIII and IX deficiencies. Response to heparin therapy, patients prone to bleeding disorders.

The Thrombin time (TT) is a test that measures the time it takes from fibrinogen to fibrin. The test is also useful for testing for therapeutic levels of unfractionated heparin and hypofibrinogenemia which can help diagnose: Fibrinogen deficiencies, dysfibrinogenemia, DIC, liver disease and fibrinolysis.
DIC, liver disease, abnormal fibrongen, streptokinase, tPA, systemic heparin, DIC, fibrinogen deficiency.
Used to evaluate identifying the cause of prolonged P and aPTT. Distinguish the presence of heparin or heparin-like anticoagulants.

A complete blood count (CBC) test measures the following: (RBC count), (WBC count), the total amount of hemoglobin in the blood, the fraction of the blood composed of RBC (hematocrit), The CBC test also provides information about the following: Average red blood cell size (MCV), hemoglobin amount per RBC (MCH), and the amount of hemoglobin relative to the size of the cell (hemoglobin concentration) per red blood cell (MCHC).

Basophils a.k.a. mast cells are particularly involved in the allergic reaction, but do not respond to bacterial or viral infections. They contain histamine and are capable of phagocytosis of antigen – antibody complexes.
Myeloproliferative disorders, hypersensitivity or inflammatory reactions, hypothyroidism (myxedema), and certain infections.

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor.
Medications that can increase the lymphocyte levels, epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene.
Medications that can decrease the lymphocyte levels, levels include abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides.
Assists in diagnosing the cause of an elevated WBC, leukemia, Hodgkin’s disease, polycythemia vera, ulcerative colitis, nephrosis, and chronic hypersensitivity states.

Elevated with basophils during allergic reactions, eosinophils (approximately 1 – 3% of the total WBC count ) are white blood cells that become active during allergic reactions, infections and other diseases.
Allergic reactions, allergies such as food and drugs, radiation, hodgkin's disease, pulmonary infections.
Inflammation and stress, also with the use of corticosteroids, late stage of AIDS

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor. Medications such as epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene can increase the WBC. Medications such as abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides can decrease the WBC levels.
Assist in diagnosing allergies, parasitic infections, drug reactions, collagen diseases, Hodgkin’s disease, and myeloproliferative disorders.
The hematocrit measures the volume in the percentage that is taken up by erythrocytes when compared to total volume. It can be calculated by this equation (Hct = RBC x MVC).
Burns, COPD, dehydration, pheochromocytoma, polycythemia vera, vomiting.
Thalassemia, iron deficiencies, acute blood loss, anemia, Hemolytic anemia, excessive fluid volume, liver disease, Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies.
Remarkably elevated WBC. Hemodilution, dehydration, abnormal size of the red blood cell.
Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.
The hematocrit measures the volume in the percentage that is taken up by erythrocytes when compared to total volume. It can be calculated by this equation (Hct = RBC x MVC).
Burns, COPD, dehydration, pheochromocytoma, polycythemia vera, vomiting.
Thalassemia, iron deficiencies, acute blood loss, anemia, Hemolytic anemia, excessive fluid volume, liver disease, Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies.
Remarkably elevated WBC. Hemodilution, dehydration, abnormal size of the red blood cell.
Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.
Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells that is responsible for transporting oxygen. Hemoglobin is also responsible for transporting other molecules such as carbon dioxide, and nitric oxide.
Burns, COPD, dehydration, pheochromocytoma, polycythemia vera, vomiting.
Thalassemia, iron deficiencies, acute blood loss, anemia, Hemolytic anemia, excessive fluid volume, liver disease, vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies.

Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, blood loss, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the progression of nonhematologic disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.
Hemoglobin is a protein found in red blood cells that is responsible for transporting oxygen. Hemoglobin is also responsible for transporting other molecules such as carbon dioxide, and nitric oxide.
Burns, COPD, dehydration, pheochromocytoma, polycythemia vera, vomiting.
Thalassemia, iron deficiencies, acute blood loss, anemia, Hemolytic anemia, excessive fluid volume, liver disease, vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies.

Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, blood loss, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the progression of nonhematologic disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.
The lymphocyte is part of the human immune system that is classified into types of white blood cells: B cells, and T cells.
Adrenal insufficiency, allergic reactions, Autoimmune diseases, infections, Thyrotoxicosis.

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor.
Medications that can increase the lymphocyte levels, epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene.
Medications that can decrease the lymphocyte levels, levels include abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides.

Assists infections such as Infectious mononucleosis, mumps, rubella, measles, influenza, hepatitis, adenovirus, coxsackie virus, poliovirus, HTLV-I, CMV, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV); protein-energy undernutrition, systemic disease chemotherapy or immunosuppressive therapy.
Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) measures the concentration of hemoglobin relative to the size of the red blood cell in a volume of PRBC. MCHC = Hgb/Hct.
Higher ranges can be found more in newborns and infants, macrocytic anemia, liver disease and folic acid deficiency.
Anemia, iron deficiency, thalassemia, lead poisoning.

Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, blood loss, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the progression of nonhematologic disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.
Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin is merely the average amount of hemoglobin that's found in a red blood cell.
Folate deficiency, Hemochromatosis, vitamin B12 deficiency.
Hemoglobinopathy, microcytic anemia, acute iron deficiency, lead poisoning, thalassemia.

Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, blood loss, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the progression of nonhematologic disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.

MCV is the short form for Mean Corpuscular Volume and is calculated by dividing the total volume of packed red blood cells (aka hematocrit) by the total number of red blood cells. MCV Is a measurement of the average amount of red blood cell volume. in patients that are anemic the MCV can be used to classify microcytic anemia, macrocytic anemia or normocytic anemia.
Alcoholism, folate deficiency, hemochromatosis, HIV/AIDS, methotrexate, vitamin B12 deficiency, liver disease.
Anemia, hemolytic anemia, hemorrhage, Iron deficiency, lead poisoning, thalassemia.

Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, blood loss, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the progression of nonhematologic disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.

A monocyte is a type of white blood cell that is produced by the bone marrow and helps to protect the body from foreign invaders, such as harmful bacteria and viruses. When there is a decreased number of monocytes in the blood, the body is more susceptible to illness.
Cancer, inflammation, infection, myeloproliferative disorder, Tuberculosis.

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor.
Medications that can increase the lymphocyte levels, epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene.
Medications that can decrease the lymphocyte levels, levels include abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides.
Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, the cause of an elevated WBC count (e.g., infection, inflammatory process).

Neutrophils are the first immune cells to arrive at a site of infection, through a process known as chemotaxis. Neutrophils are the most common type of white blood cell, comprising about 50-70% of all white blood cells. A deficiency of neutrophils is called neutropenia.
Acute stress, Diabetic ketoacidosis, infections, inflammation, & tumors.
Aplastic anemia, chemotherapy, folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies, bone marrow infiltration.

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor.
Medications that can increase the lymphocyte levels, epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene.
Medications that can decrease the lymphocyte levels, levels include abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides.
Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, the cause of an elevated WBC count (e.g., infection, inflammatory process).

Platelets are fragments of the cells in bone marrow, called megakaryocytes. Stimulated by the hormone thrombopoietin, platelets break off the megakaryocytes and enter the bloodstream, where they circulate for about ten days before ending their short lives in the spleen. Platelets play a fundamental role in hemostasis, bleeding and clotting formation.
Acute blood loss, cancer, Thrombocytopenia, infection, iron deficiency, myelofibrosis, Pre-eclampsia, Polycythemia vera, Splenectomy.

Alcohol, Aplastic anemia, bone marrow infiltration, blood transfusions, chemotherapy, DIC, Hemolytic anemia, HIV, Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT), Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, cephalosporins.

Increased after exercise, higher altitudes, and oral contraceptives. Decreased before menstruation, and meds such as chemotherapy, chloramphenicol, H2-blockers (cimetidine, ranitidine), hydralazine, Indocin, isoniazid, abx such as levofloxacin, quinidine, streptomycin. Sulfonamides, thiazide diuretics.

Used to evaluate thrombocytopenia, thrombocytosis including aplastic anemia, hypersplenism, marrow involvement with malignancy, autoimmune platelet destruction (either idiopathic or drug-related), sepsis, or folate or cobalamin deficiency and suspected bleeding disorders.

A red blood cell or erythrocyte is developed in the bone marrow, and also is the most common type of cell in blood. Red blood cells deliver oxygen molecules throughout the body. T cells circulate for approximately 100 – 120 days in the body before they are taken up by the macrophages.
Congenital heart diseases, cor pulmonale, dehydration, high altitudes, hypoxia, pulmonary fibrosis, thalassemia.
Alcohol abuse, anemia, hemoglobinopathies, hemolysis, hemorrhage, liver disease, chemotherapy.

Used to evaluate suspected bleeding disorders, anemia, RBC destruction such as hemolytic anemia, monitor effects of acute or chronic blood loss, polycythemia vera, COPD, response of medications, non-hematological disorders such as liver disease, hypothyroidism, adrenal dysfunction, bone marrow failure, malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease.

A red blood cell or erythrocyte is developed in the bone marrow, and also is the most common type of cell in blood. Red blood cells deliver oxygen molecules throughout the body. T cells circulate for approximately 100 – 120 days in the body before they are taken up by the macrophages.
Congenital heart diseases, cor pulmonale, dehydration, high altitudes, hypoxia, pulmonary fibrosis, thalassemia.
Alcohol abuse, anemia, hemoglobinopathies, hemolysis, hemorrhage, liver disease, chemotherapy.

Used to evaluate suspected bleeding disorders, anemia, RBC destruction such as hemolytic anemia, monitor effects of acute or chronic blood loss, polycythemia vera, COPD, response of medications, non-hematological disorders such as liver disease, hypothyroidism, adrenal dysfunction, bone marrow failure, malabsorption syndromes, cancer, and renal disease.
The RBC Distribution Width measures the variation of the red blood cells width.
Used to evaluate hematologic disorders, anemia, fluid balances, neoplasm, immunological abnormality. Monitor the response to medications or chemotherapy to drugs that can cause blood dyscrasias.

The white blood cell count has two components which consist of the number of leukocytes, and the differential, which measures percent of each type of leukocyte that are present. These are cells, in the immune system ( which derive from the bone marrow) that defend the body against foreign bodies and infectious diseases.
Infection, stress, trauma, inflammation, tissue necrosis, leukemia, anemia.
Bone marrow failure, chemotherapy, bone marrow diseases, autoimmune diseases, liver disease, systemic lupus, vitamin B12 deficiencies.

Stress, splenectomy, final stages of pregnancy/labor.
Medications that can increase the lymphocyte levels, epi, allopurinol, aspirin, chloroform, epinephrine, heparin, quinine, steroids, and triamterene.
Medications that can decrease the lymphocyte levels, levels include abx, anticonvulsants, antihistamines, antimetabolites, barbiturates, chemotherapy, diuretics, and sulfonamides.
Assists infections, inflammation, tissue necrosis, or leukemic neoplasia.

A comprehensive metabolic panel is a group of blood tests. They provide an overall picture of your body's chemical balance and metabolism. Metabolism refers to all the physical and chemical processes in the body that use energy.

Sodium is an important cation found mostly in the extracellular fluid determined primarily by the volume status of a patient. Sodium is important in regulating H2O distribution in the body, osmotic pressure, neuromuscular function, acid-base balance and electrolyte balance.
Cushing's syndrome, dehydration, diabetes insipidus/mellitus, excessive sweating, hypertonic saline.
Ace inhibitors, ATN, AIDS, adrenal insufficiency, CHF, Cirrhosis, diarrhea, hypothyroidism, nasogastric suctioning, SIADH.
Overall kidney function, abx, laxatives, steroids, diuretics, and diet.
Used to evaluate acid-base balance, water balance, water intoxication, and dehydration. Also used to monitor the effectiveness of medications such as diuretics.

Potassium is an important cation found mostly in the intracellular fluid that is responsible for a variety of different functions such as neuromuscular function, contraction of skeletal smooth and cardiac muscle. It also helps to maintain acid-base balance. K + greater than 7.0 can cause peaked T waves and ventricular dysrhythmias.
Acidosis, Addison's disease, Dehydration, infections, Renal failure (acute and chronic), Hemolysis, transfusions, Ace inhibitors, NSAIDs, spironolactone.
Alkalosis, ascites, burns, Cushing's syndrome, diarrhea, diuretics, Insulin, and vomiting.

Hemolysis, tourniquets, Drugs: abx, antineoplastic drugs, captopril, epinephrine, heparin, histamine, isoniazid, lithium, mannitol, potassium-sparing diuretics, potassium supplements, insulin, Kayexalate, and succinylcholine.

Used to evaluate electrolytes imbalances, patients receiving hemodialysis, muscle weakness, hepatic encephalopathy, cardiac arrhythmia and renal failure. K+ levels are also used to monitor conditions such as DKA and any intravenous therapy for fluid replacement. Monitor known or suspected acidosis, as potassium shifts from RBCs into the extracellular fluid in acidotic states.

The C02 is actually measured as bicarbonate on a BMP. The bicarbonate (or total CO2) is in an ion that acts as a buffer against pH disturbances. Bicarb (HCO3) is primarily converted into CO2 in order to be excreted from the lungs. HCO3 is important in calculating the anion gap in diagnosing potential respiratory or metabolic disorders.

Drugs: aldosterone, barbiturates, bicarbonates, hydrocortisone, loop diuretics, and steroids.
Drugs that may cause decreased levels include methicillin, furadantin, tetracycline, thiazide diuretics.
Used to evaluate acid-base status- decreased CO2 in compensated metabolic acidosis & respiratory alkalosis. Increased CO2 in compensated metabolic alkalosis & respiratory acidosis.

Chloride is a type of electrolyte. It works with other electrolytes such as potassium, sodium, and carbon dioxide (CO2) to help keep the proper balance of the body's fluids and maintain the body's acid – base balance.
Diarrhea, dehydration, hyperparathyroidism, excessive saline, renal failure, respiratory acidosis.
Adrenal insufficiency, cushing's syndrome, DKA, gastric suctioning, SIADH, renal failure, bicarbonates, corticosteroids and diuretics

NaCl infusions can increase the chloride level. Drugs such as acetazolamide, ammonium chloride, androgens, cortisone preparations, estrogens, hydrochlorothiazide, and NSAIDS can increase Cl levels.
Cl levels may decrease in the presence of loop & thiazide diuretics, aldosterone, bicarbonates, corticosteroids, cortisone.

Used to evaluate electrolytes imbalances, and acid-base status- distinguishing between types of acidosis such as (hyperchloremic vs. anion gap), monitor effectiveness of medications that increase or decrease overall serum chloride levels.
The BUN is a by-product of protein metabolism. Urea nitrogen is what forms when protein breaks down. The BUN is one measure of adequate renal function, but is not as specific as serum creatinine.
Burns, dehydration, G.I. bleeding, pre-renal azotemia, postrenal attractions, renal failure, shock, aminoglycosides.
Liver failure, infancy, nephrotic syndrome, hemodilution, starvation, malabsorbtion.

Pregnancy, protein intake, hydration status, GI bleeds.
Drugs that increase BUN: allopurinol, aminoglycosides, cephalosporins, chloral hydrate, cisplatin, nephrotoxic drugs, lasix, Indocin, methotrexate, methyldopa, propranolol, rifampin, spironolactone, tetracyclines, thiazide diuretics.
Drugs that decrease BUN: abx such as chloramphenicol and streptomycin.
Used to evaluate renal and liver function. Monitor hydration status and the effects of nephrotoxic and hepatotoxic medications.

Creatinine is a breakdown product of creatine, which is an essential part of the muscle. A measurement of the serum creatinine level in conjunction with the BUN is directly related to renal function. Thus, in cases where renal function is normal, serum creatinine will remain low. Conversely, when renal function is suboptimal, serum creatinine levels will rise.
Chronic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis, rhabdomyolysis, diabetic nephropathy, pyelonephritis, shock, dehydration, congestive heart failure, atherosclerosis.
Excessive fluid intake, muscular dystrophy, myasthenia gravis.
Drugs that can increase serum creatinine: ACE inhibitors, aminoglycosides, chemotherapy, and other nephrotoxic drugs, such as cephalosporins.
Used to evaluate renal function and the degree of nephron damage in known kidney disease. Monitor the effectiveness of nephrotoxic medications in the presence of renal disease.
A blood glucose test measures the amount of sugar called glucose in a sample of your blood. Glucose is a major source of energy for most cells in the body, including those in the brain.
Hyperglycemia can be indicative of diabetes mellitus (DM).

IV fluids with dextrose, pregnancy, anesthesia, stroke, myocardial infarction, shock, exercise, burns.
Drugs that may increase glucose: statins, corticosteroids, antidepressants (tricyclics), antipsychotics, beta blockers, diuretics, epinephrine, estrogens, isoniazid, lithium, niacin, phenothiazines, phenytoin, salicylates (acute toxicity), and gluca­gon.
Drugs decreased glucose include sulfonylureas, acetaminophen, alcohol, steroids, insulin, monoamine oxidase inhibitors.
Critical Values: > 4 Weeks: ≥ 400 or ≤ 50 mg/dL, < 4 Weeks: ≥ 400 or ≤ 40 mg/dL
Assists hypoglycemia, insulinoma, diabetes, and evaluate for disorders such as carbohydrate metabolism.

Calcium is most abundant mineral in the body and is essential for the functional integrity of the nervous and muscular systems. Ca+ homeostasis is maintained by the parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, and Calcitonin. It is necessary for cardiac function, blood coagulation, maintains cell membrane and capillary permeability. Also, stabilizes myocardial membranes associated with hyperkalemia. Approximate one half the total calcium in the blood exists in its free (ionized) form, the other half is protein-bound (mostly with albumin). When measuring the serum calcium level, we measure the protein bound and ionized form collectively. Serum calcium levels parallel the albumin. When albumin is low, so will the serum calcium. Note that the total serum calcium level will decrease roughly 0.8mg for every 1-g decrease in the serum albumin level. An advantage of testing only the ionized form is that it is unaffected by changes in serum albumin levels.
Bone cancer, diarrhea, decreased pH, ATN, hyperparathyroidism, Paget's disease of the bone, renal failure.
Alcoholism, pancreatitis, hyperphosphatemia, magnesium & vitamin D deficiency, tumor lysis, vomiting, ketoacidosis.

Hemodialysis, icterus, hemostasis, IV mixing of medications. Medications that may increase calcium levels include steroids, some antacids, calcitriol, calcium salts, diuretics (long-term), oral contraceptives, parathyroid extract, parathyroid hormone, prednisone, progesterone, tamoxifen, vitamin A, and vitamin D. Albuterol, alprostadil, aminoglycosides, anticonvulsants, calcitonin, diuretics (initially), glucagon, glucocorticoids, glucose, magnesium salts, methicillin, phosphates, sodium sulfate (given intravenously) and trazodone may decrease serum calcium levels.
Critical Values: <6 or >13 mg/dL, Ionized calcium: <2.2 or >7 mg/dL
Used to evaluate diseases of bone, kidney, parathyroid gland, or gastrointestinal tract, cardiac arrhythmias, renal failure, calcium and vitamin D deficiencies.

Most organ functions, including those of neuromuscular tissue depend on magnesium. Magnesium plays important role in muscle relaxation, nerve impulse transmission, and electrolyte balance. Half of magnesium is found in the bone, and the other half exists intracellularly. Most magnesium is bound to ATP, therefore, that's why it's nearly critical in all metabolic processes.
Hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, renal failure, magnesium salts, severe dehydration, laxatives.
Alcoholism, DKA, diarrhea, hyperparathyroidism, albuterol, calcium salts, diuretics, malnutrition, chronic renal disease.

Hemodialysis, IV mixing of medications. Medications that may increase magnesium levels include acetylsalicylic acid and progesterone. Albuterol, aminoglycosides, amphotericin B, bendroflumethiazide, chlorthalidone, citrates, cyclosporines, cisplatin, digoxin, gentamicin, glucagon, and oral contraceptives may decrease serum magnesium levels.
Used to evaluate electrolyte imbalances, suspected renal failure, alcoholism, cardiac dysrhythmias. Monitor the effects of various drugs on magnesium levels.

Phosphorus in the body exists in the form of phosphate and is found in the bones (80%), teeth, nucleic acids, lipids, proteins, and enzymes. When "phosphorus" is requested, it is the inorganic phosphate that is measured. Most phosphorus is bound to calcium, which lowers overall serum calcium levels. Abnormal phosphorus levels are likely related to kidney diseases or abnormal calcium levels.
Renal failure, hypothyroidism, liver disease, vitamin D toxicity, hypocalcemia, acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, hemolytic anemia.
Salicylate poisoning, acute gout, hyperparathyroidism, hypokalemia, vitamin D deficiency, alkalosis, sepsis, gram-negative bacterial septicemia, hypercalcemia, alcoholism, rickets, diabetes.

Hemodialysis can increase PO4- levels. Medications that increase PO4- include anabolic steroids, adrenergic blockers, ergocalciferol, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, methicillin (occurs with nephrotoxicity), oral contraceptives, parathyroid extract, phosphates, sodium etidronate, tetracycline and vitamin D. Acetazolamide, albuterol, aluminum salts, anesthetics, anticonvulsants, calcitonin, epinephrine, glucocorticoids, glucose, insulin, mannitol, and oral contraceptives can decrease the PO4-.

Albumin is produced in the liver and is considered one of the most abundant proteins that are found in the plasma. Albumin is necessary to keep fluid from leaking out of the blood vessels. It is also essential for transporting nutrients, hormones and other proteins that are responsible for clotting.

Burns, chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, crohn's disease, diabetes mellitus, glomerulonephritis, hemodilution, hodgkins lymphoma, inflammatory bowel disease (IBS), leukemia, malabsorption, malnutrition, preeclampsia.
Enalapril can increase albumin levels, tylenol, dextran, estrogen, NSAIDS, phenytoin, prednisone (high doses), trazodone, and valproic acid can all decrease serum albumin levels.
Used to evaluate liver disease, chronic illness, nutritional status.

Proteins consist of amino acids and is essential for all physiological functions in the body. In the plasma, protein is made up of 2 significant proteins; globulin and as well albumin. When testing for a total serum protein, the values are separated into these two proteins. Globulin is made of alpha, beta, and gamma types found in the liver, and albumin is mainly found in the liver and is responsible for maintaining the oncotic pressure inside the blood vessels.
Steroids, dehydration, glucocorticoids, liver disease, polyclonal gammopathies, viral hepatitis, epinephrine, androgens.
Anorexia, agammaglobulinemia, diabetes mellitus, burns, liver disease, protein deficiency, malabsorption, nephrotic syndrome.

Hemodialysis, venous stasis, medications such as anabolic steroids, angiotensin, anticonvulsants, corticosteroids, corticotropin, digitalis, furosemide, insulin, oral contraceptives, progesterone, contrast agents, and thyroid agents can increase the TP. Medications such as acetylsalicylic acid, benzene, carvedilol, citrates, floxuridine, laxatives, mercury compounds, oral contraceptives, rifampin, trimethadione, and valproic acid can decrease the TP.
Used to evaluate the nutritional status and also edema in patients with low protein and albumin levels.

Alanine Transaminase is an enzyme that is produced by the liver and helps the body metabolize proteins. When the liver is damaged and not functioning properly, this enzyme is released into the bloodstream which causes the ALT levels to increase. In most cases, hepatocellular injury is associated with serum AST levels lower than the ALT. An AST / ALT ratio of 2:1 or higher is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease, especially in the setting of an elevated (GGT) gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase.
Acetaminophen toxicity, alcohol, hepatitis, cholangitis, biliary obstruction, liver abscess, liver cancer, liver failure, mononucleosis, shock liver, hepatotoxicity drugs.
Vitamin B6 deficiency, pyridoxal phosphate deficiency.

Hemolysis falsely increases AST values. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the AST and cause cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the AST may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, allopurinol, amiodarone, anabolic steroids, anticonvulsants, azithromycin, captopril, cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluconazole, fluoroquinolones, gentamicin, Indocin, interferon, IL-2, low molecular weight heparin, methyldopa, MAO inhibitors, naproxen, nifedipine, nitrofurans, oral contraceptives, procainamide, quinine, ranitidine, retinol, sulfonylureas, tetracyclines, tobramycin, and verapamil.
Assists acute liver failure, hepatocellular cell injury second to hepatotoxic medications, shock liver, treatment response from drugs to treat liver disease, hepatitis screening.

Alkaline Phosphatase is a hydrolase enzyme produced by the liver that is responsible for moving phosphate groups from different types of molecules, proteins, alkaloids, and nucleotides. Although present in most tissue, ALP is most abundant in the bone and in the liver. During pregnancy, high levels can be found in the placenta.
Obstruction of the bile duct, bone and liver cancer, hyperparathyroidism, Paget's disease, third trimester pregnancy, osteogenic sarcoma, Rickets, hepatotoxic drugs.

Medications such as allopurinol, antibiotics, birth control pills, diabetes medications, chlorpromazine, cortisone, male hormones, methyldopa, narcotics, NSAIDs, propranolol, tranquilizers and TCA's can alter the alk phos.
Assists liver, bone, intestinal, and parathyroid diseases.

Aspartate Transaminase is usually found in small amounts in the body such as in skeletal muscle and the heart, however high quantities are produced in the liver in the heart when damage or disease is present. AST is commonly used in liver function testing to determine the health of the liver. AST is less specific for liver disease compared to the other enzymes that are in the panel. In most cases, hepatocellular injury is associated with serum AST levels lower than the ALT. An AST / ALT ratio of 2:1 or higher is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease, especially in the setting of an elevated (GGT) gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase.
Acute viral hepatitis, Alcoholic hepatitis, cholangitis, liver abscess, liver cancer, right-sided heart failure, shock liver, hepatic toxic drugs, Reye's syndrome, Wilson's disease.

Hemolysis falsely increases AST values. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the AST and cause cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the AST may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, allopurinol, amiodarone, anabolic steroids, anticonvulsants, azithromycin, captopril, cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluconazole, fluoroquinolones, gentamicin, Indocin, interferon, IL-2, low molecular weight heparin, methyldopa, MAO inhibitors, naproxen, nifedipine, nitrofurans, oral contraceptives, procainamide, quinine, ranitidine, retinol, sulfonylureas, tetracyclines, tobramycin, and verapamil.
Assists acute liver failure, hepatocellular cell injury particularly diseases resulting in the destruction of hepatocytes. Treatment response from drugs to treat liver disease, hepatitis screening.

Bilirubin is made when old red blood cells break down (heme catabolism). Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that is found in everybody's blood and stool. When attached to sugar, we call this "direct" or "conjugated" bilirubin, and without the sugar is called "in direct" or "unconjugated" bilirubin. All the bilirubin in the body combined is referred to as the total bilirubin.
Alcohol, biliary obstruction, cirrhosis, gallstones, hepatitis, liver cancer, Dublin – Johnson syndrome, Gilberts syndrome, hepatotoxic drugs.

Light can alter total bilirubin. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the TBili and by causing cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the TBili may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, allopurinol, amiodarone, anabolic steroids, anticonvulsants, azithromycin, captopril, cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluconazole, fluoroquinolones, gentamicin, Indocin, interferon, IL-2, low molecular weight heparin, methyldopa, MAO inhibitors, naproxen, nifedipine, nitrofurans, oral contraceptives, procainamide, quinine, ranitidine, retinol, sulfonylureas, tetracyclines, tobramycin, and verapamil.
Assists obstructive jaundice, liver and biliary function or disease, jaundice in newborns and the effects on phototherapy.

The kidney function test also known as KFT, are tests used to measure how well the kidneys are functioning. It is important to note that some or all of these functions may be diminished or absent in some diseases while other tests may be completely normal.

The BUN is a by-product of protein metabolism. Urea nitrogen is what forms when protein breaks down. The BUN is one measure of adequate renal function, but not as much when compared to serum creatinine.
Burns, dehydration, G.I. bleeding, pre-renal azotemia, postrenal attractions, renal failure, shock, aminoglycosides.
Liver failure, infancy, nephrotic syndrome, hemodilution, starvation, malabsorbtion.

Pregnancy, protein intake, hydration status, GI bleeds.
Drugs that increase BUN: allopurinol, aminoglycosides, cephalosporins, chloral hydrate, cisplatin, nephrotoxic drugs, lasix, Indocin, methotrexate, methyldopa, propranolol, rifampin, spironolactone, tetracyclines, thiazide diuretics.
Drugs that decrease BUN: abx such as chloramphenicol and streptomycin.
Used to evaluate renal and liver function. Monitor hydration status and the effects of nephrotoxic and hepatotoxic medications.

The ratio between Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) and Creatinine is used to measure kidney function. Both BUN & Creatinine are byproducts of muscle breakdown. When kidney function is reduced, a rise of BUN & Creatinine will be noticed. In cases of dehydration, the BUN-to-creatinine ratio may be higher than 20:1, as the kidney counters by making the urine more concentrated. The BUN:Cr ratio does not act as a lone test to determine kidney failure.
Dehydration, renal failure, GI Bleeding, kidney stones, increased catabolism
Acute tubular necrosis (ATN), liver disease, low protein intake, cirrhosis, pregnancy, SIADH, rhabdomyolysis.

Pregnancy, protein intake, hydration status, GI bleeds.
Drugs that increase BUN: allopurinol, aminoglycosides, cephalosporins, chloral hydrate, cisplatin, nephrotoxic drugs, lasix, Indocin, methotrexate, methyldopa, propranolol, rifampin, spironolactone, tetracyclines, thiazide diuretics.
Drugs that decrease BUN: abx such as chloramphenicol and streptomycin.
Used to evaluate renal and liver function. Monitor hydration status and the effects of nephrotoxic and hepatotoxic medications.
Creatinine is the breakdown of creatine phosphate which is filtered by the kidneys. The Creatinine clearance (CC) is a substitute for GFR which can vary depending on the muscle mass of the patient.
Dehydration, renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, kidney stones, increased catabolism.
Acute tubular necrosis (ATN), liver disease, low protein intake, cirrhosis, pregnancy, SIADH, rhabdomyolysis.
Drugs that can increase serum creatinine: ACE inhibitors, aminoglycosides, chemotherapy, and other nephrotoxic drugs, such as cephalosporins.
Used to evaluate renal function and the degree of nephron damage in known kidney disease. Monitor the effectiveness of nephrotoxic medications in the presence of renal disease.

Creatinine is a breakdown product of creatine, which is an essential part of the muscle. A measurement of the serum creatinine level in conjunction with the BUN is directly related to renal function. Thus, in cases where renal function is normal, serum creatinine will remain low. Conversely, when renal function is suboptimal, serum creatinine levels will rise.
Chronic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis, rhabdomyolysis, diabetic nephropathy, pyelonephritis, shock, dehydration, congestive heart failure, atherosclerosis.
Excessive fluid intake, muscular dystrophy, myasthenia gravis.
Drugs that can increase serum creatinine: ACE inhibitors, aminoglycosides, chemotherapy, and other nephrotoxic drugs, such as cephalosporins.
Used to evaluate renal function and the degree of nephron damage in known kidney disease. Monitor the effectiveness of nephrotoxic medications in the presence of renal disease.

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is a test used to help diagnose Kidney disease. The GFR measures the functions of the kidneys, explicitly measuring how well the glomeruli are filtering blood. On average GFR is higher in African-Americans than in Caucasians.
Acromegaly, DM, increased CO, hypothyroidism, infection.
Decreased renal perfusion, CHF, dehydration, hemorrhaging, shock, renal failure, nephrotoxic drugs.
Drugs that can increase serum creatinine: ACE inhibitors, aminoglycosides, chemotherapy, and other nephrotoxic drugs, such as cephalosporins.
Used to evaluate renal function and the degree of nephron damage in known kidney disease. Monitor the effectiveness of nephrotoxic medications in the presence of renal disease.

Phosphorus in the body exists in the form of phosphate and is found in the bones (80%), teeth, nucleic acids, lipids, proteins, and enzymes. When "phosphorus" is requested, it is the inorganic phosphate that is measured. Most phosphorus is bound to calcium. Abnormal phosphorus levels are likely related to kidney diseases or abnormal calcium levels.
Renal failure, hypothyroidism, liver disease, vitamin D toxicity, hypocalcemia, acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, hemolytic anemia.
Salicylate poisoning, acute gout, hyperparathyroidism, hypokalemia, vitamin D deficiency, alkalosis, sepsis, gram-negative bacterial septicemia, hypercalcemia, alcoholism, rickets, diabetes.

Hemodialysis can increase PO4- levels. Medications that increase PO4- include anabolic steroids, adrenergic blockers, ergocalciferol, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, methicillin (occurs with nephrotoxicity), oral contraceptives, parathyroid extract, phosphates, sodium etidronate, tetracycline and vitamin D. Acetazolamide, albuterol, aluminum salts, anesthetics, anticonvulsants, calcitonin, epinephrine, glucocorticoids, glucose, insulin, mannitol, and oral contraceptives can decrease the PO4-.

Potassium is an important cation found mostly in the intracellular fluid that is responsible for a variety of different functions such as neuromuscular function, contraction of skeletal smooth and Cardiac muscle. It also helps to maintain acid-base balance. K + greater than 7.0 can cause peaked T waves and ventricular dysrhythmias.
Acidosis, addison's disease, dehydration, infections, renal failure (acute and chronic), hemolysis, transfusions, ace inhibitors, NSAIDs, spironolactone.
Alkalosis, ascites, burns, Cushing's syndrome, diarrhea, Diuretics, Insulin, and vomiting.

Hemolysis, tourniquets, Drugs: abx, antineoplastic drugs, captopril, epinephrine, heparin, histamine, isoniazid, lithium, mannitol, potassium-sparing diuretics, potassium supplements, insulin, kayexalate, and succinylcholine.

Used to evaluate electrolytes imbalances, patients receiving hemodialysis, muscle weakness, hepatic encephalopathy, cardiac arrhythmia and renal failure. K+ levels are also used to monitor conditions such as DKA and any intravenous therapy for fluid replacement. Monitor known or suspected acidosis, as potassium shifts from RBCs into the extracellular fluid in acidotic states.

Sodium is an important cation found mostly in the extracellular fluid determined primarily by the volume status of a patient. Sodium is important in regulating H2O distribution in the body, osmotic pressure, neuromuscular function, acid-base balance and electrolyte balance.
Cushing's syndrome, dehydration, diabetes insipidus/mellitus, excessive sweating, hypertonic saline.
Ace inhibitors, ATN, AIDS, adrenal insufficiency, CHF, Cirrhosis, diarrhea, hypothyroidism, nasogastric suctioning, SIADH.
Overall kidney function, abx, laxatives, steroids, diuretics, and diet.
Used to evaluate acid-base balance, water balance, water intoxication, and dehydration. Also used to monitor the effectiveness of medications such as diuretics.

When liver cells are damaged or destroyed, the two primary enzymes (AST, ALT) in the cells, leak out into the blood. The liver function test measures the enzymes that are released by the liver when its inflamed or damaged. It also shows how well the liver is performing its daily functions - producing protein and clearing bilirubin.

Alanine Transaminase is an enzyme that is produced by the liver and helps the body metabolize proteins. When the liver is damaged and not functioning properly, this enzyme is released into the bloodstream which causes the ALT levels to increase. In most cases, hepatocellular injury is associated with serum AST levels lower than the ALT. An AST / ALT ratio of 2:1 or higher is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease, especially in the setting of an elevated (GGT) gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase.
Acetaminophen toxicity, alcohol, hepatitis, cholangitis, biliary obstruction, liver abscess, liver cancer, liver failure, mononucleosis, shock liver, hepatotoxicity drugs.
Vitamin B6 deficiency, pyridoxal phosphate deficiency.

Hemolysis falsely increases AST values. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the AST and cause cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the AST may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, allopurinol, amiodarone, anabolic steroids, anticonvulsants, azithromycin, captopril, cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluconazole, fluoroquinolones, gentamicin, Indocin, interferon, IL-2, low molecular weight heparin, methyldopa, MAO inhibitors, naproxen, nifedipine, nitrofurans, oral contraceptives, procainamide, quinine, ranitidine, retinol, sulfonylureas, tetracyclines, tobramycin, and verapamil.
Assists acute liver failure, hepatocellular cell injury second to hepatotoxic medications, shock liver, treatment response from drugs to treat liver disease, hepatitis screening.

Albumin is produced in the liver and is considered one of the most abundant proteins that are found in the plasma. Albumin is necessary to keep fluid from leaking out of the blood vessels. It is also essential for transporting nutrients, hormones and other proteins that are responsible for clotting.

Burns, chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, crohn's disease, diabetes mellitus, glomerulonephritis, hemodilution, hodgkins lymphoma, Inflammatory bowel disease, leukemia, malabsorption, malnutrition, preeclampsia.
Enalapril can increase albumin levels, tylenol, dextran, estrogen, NSAIDS, phenytoin, prednisone (high doses), trazodone, and valproic acid can all decrease serum albumin levels.
Used to evaluate liver disease, chronic illness, nutritional status.

Alkaline Phosphatase is a hydrolase enzyme produced by the liver that is responsible for moving phosphate groups from different types of molecules, proteins, alkaloids, and nucleotides. Although present in most tissue, ALP is most abundant in the bone and in the liver. During pregnancy, high levels can be found in the placenta.
