Obstruction of the bile duct, bone and liver cancer, hyperparathyroidism, Paget's disease, third trimester pregnancy, osteogenic sarcoma, Rickets, hepatotoxic drugs.

Medications such as allopurinol, antibiotics, birth control pills, diabetes medications, chlorpromazine, cortisone, male hormones, methyldopa, narcotics, NSAIDs, propranolol, tranquilizers and TCA's can alter the alk phos.
Assists liver, bone, intestinal, and parathyroid diseases.

Ammonia is a by-product of protein catabolism - formed when protein is broken down by bacteria in the intestines. Ammonia is then converted urea by the liver and subsequently eliminated in the urine. When the liver is unable to break down the ammonia, ammonia levels rise which can help diagnose liver diseases, hepatic encephalopathy, and Reyes syndrome. Moreover, when portal blood flow to the liver is modified (e.g., in portal hypertension), ammonia cannot reach the liver to be catabolized, thus blood ammonia rises.
G.I. bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy, liver failure, renal disease, Reye's syndrome, diuretics, depakote.

Hemolysis increases ammonia levels due to the RBCs containing about three times the ammonia content of plasma. Smoking, exertion, and medications such as acetazolamide, alcohol, ammonium chloride, barbiturates, diuretics, narcotics, and TPN. Broad-Spectrum antibiotics, lactobacillus, lactulose, levodopa, and potassium salts can decrease serum ammonia levels.
Assists patients with advanced liver disease, hepatic comas, and metabolism.

Aspartate Transaminase is usually found in small amounts in the body such as in skeletal muscle and the heart, however high quantities are produced in the liver in the heart when damage or disease is present. AST is commonly used in liver function testing to determine the health of the liver. AST is less specific for liver disease compared to the other enzymes that are in the panel. In most cases, hepatocellular injury is associated with serum AST levels lower than the ALT. An AST / ALT ratio of 2:1 or higher is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease, especially in the setting of an elevated (GGT) gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase.
Acute viral hepatitis, Alcoholic hepatitis, cholangitis, liver abscess, liver cancer, right-sided heart failure, shock liver, hepatic toxic drugs, Reye's syndrome, Wilson's disease.

Hemolysis falsely increases AST values. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the AST and cause cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the AST may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, allopurinol, amiodarone, anabolic steroids, anticonvulsants, azithromycin, captopril, cephalosporins, clindamycin, fluconazole, fluoroquinolones, gentamicin, Indocin, interferon, IL-2, low molecular weight heparin, methyldopa, MAO inhibitors, naproxen, nifedipine, nitrofurans, oral contraceptives, procainamide, quinine, ranitidine, retinol, sulfonylureas, tetracyclines, tobramycin, and verapamil.
Assists acute liver failure, hepatocellular cell injury particularly diseases resulting in the destruction of hepatocytes. Treatment response from drugs to treat liver disease, hepatitis screening.

Bilirubin is made when old red blood cells break down (heme catabolism). Hemoglobin is released from RBCs and broken down to heme and globin molecules. Heme is then catabolized to form biliverdin, which is transformed into bilirubin. Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that is found in everybody's blood and stool. When attached to a sugar, we call this "direct" or "conjugated" bilirubin, and without the sugar is called "indirect" or "unconjugated" bilirubin which is then stored in the gallbladder as bile. All the bilirubin in the body combined is referred to as the "total bilirubin."
Alcohol, biliary obstruction, cirrhosis, gallstones, hepatitis, liver cancer, Dublin – Johnson syndrome, Gilberts syndrome, hepatotoxic drugs.

Hemolysis and lipemia can produce erroneous results. Blood products and medications such as allopurinol, anabolic steroids, antibiotics, cholinergics, codeine, dextran, diuretics, epinephrine, MAO inhibitors, morphine, oral contraceptives, salicylates, steroids, sulfonamides, theophylline, and vitamin A can increase the direct bilirubin. Conversely, barbiturates, caffeine, penicillin, and salicylates (high doses) can decrease the direct bilirubin.
Assists obstructive jaundice, liver and biliary function or disease, jaundice in newborns and the effects on phototherapy.

Bilirubin is made when old red blood cells break down (heme catabolism). Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that is found in everybody's blood and stool. When attached to sugar, we call this "direct" or "conjugated" bilirubin, and without the sugar is called "in direct" or "unconjugated" bilirubin. All the bilirubin in the body combined is referred to as the total bilirubin.
Alcohol, biliary obstruction, cirrhosis, gallstones, hepatitis, liver cancer, Dublin – Johnson syndrome, Gilberts syndrome, hepatotoxic drugs.

Light can alter total bilirubin. Medications such as anabolic steroids, androgens, benzodiazepines, erythromycin, estrogens, contraceptives, penicillins, sulfonamides, and tamoxifen may increase the TBili and by causing cholestasis. Medications that may cause hepatocellular damage subsequently increasing the TBili may include acetaminophen (hepatotoxic), acetylsalicylic acid, amiodarone, steroids, antibiotics and NSAIDs.
Assists obstructive jaundice, liver and biliary function or disease, jaundice in newborns and the effects on phototherapy.

Proteins consist of amino acids and is essential for all physiological functions in the body. In the plasma, protein is made up of 2 significant proteins; globulin and as well albumin. When testing for a total serum protein, the values are separated into these two proteins. Globulin is made of alpha, beta , and gamma types found in the liver, and albumin is mainly found in the liver as well responsible for maintaining the oncotic pressure inside the blood vessels.
Steroids, dehydration, glucocorticoids, liver disease, polyclonal gammopathies, viral hepatitis, epinephrine, androgens.
Anorexia, agammaglobuninemia, diabetes mellitus, burns, liver disease, protein deficiency, malabsorption, nephrotic syndrome.

Hemodialysis, venous stasis, medications such as anabolic steroids, angiotensin, anticonvulsants, corticosteroids, corticotropin, digitalis, furosemide, insulin, oral contraceptives, progesterone, contrast agents, and thyroid agents can increase the TP. Medications such as acetylsalicylic acid, benzene, carvedilol, citrates, floxuridine, laxatives, mercury compounds, oral contraceptives, rifampin, trimethadione, and valproic acid can decrease the TP.
Used to evaluate the nutritional status and also edema in patients with low protein and albumin levels.

Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase is an enzyme that is used to transport amino acids across cellular membranes. GGTP is the most sensitive liver enzyme in detecting cholecystitis, biliary obstructions, or cholangitis. The highest concentrations are typically found in the biliary tract and liver. However, small amounts can also be located in the heart, brain, prostate, intestines, spleen, and kidneys. This enzyme is used in conjunction with ALP to help detect liver diseases and bile duct injuries. GGTP is also useful in recognizing chronic alcohol ingestion as enzyme levels are elevated in approximately 75% of alcoholics. In general, elevated levels of Gamma-Glutamyl transferase can indicate liver damage but is not specific.

Alcohol hepatitis, biliary obstruction, carbamazepine, mononucleosis, liver cancer, phenytoin, viral hepatitis, Cholestasis, jaundice, myocardial infarction, pancreatitis, CMV, pancreatic cancer, hepatic tumors, necrosis or metastasis.
Late pregnancy and oral contraceptives can decrease GGTP levels. Medications such as phenobarbital, phenytoin, and alcohol can increase levels.

Assists patients with hepatobiliary disease. Screen for alcoholism and determining whether marked elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are due to skeletal disease (which have a normal GGT level) or indicate the presence of hepatobiliary disease (which will show an elevated GGT).

Amylase is used to help diagnose pancreatic disorders, such as pancreatitis. Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down complex carbohydrates, i.e.( starch ) into sugar. There are two types of amylase, alpha, and beta. Alpha is found in the saliva, and beta amylase is located in the pancreas. Amylase is typically secreted from the pancreatic acinar cell into the pancreatic duct and then into the duodenum. Once in the intestines, amylase is broken down into simple sugars.
When there is damage to the acinar cells (as in pancreatitis) or pancreatic obstructions, there is an overflow of amylase into the intra-pancreatic lymph system and peritoneum. Blood vessels that drain the peritoneum will then pick up the excess amylase thus raising the serum amylase level usually within 12 hours of onset. Typically, serum amylase levels will return to normal, considering that the kidney function is reasonable since the kidneys clear amylase.

Acute pancreatitis, alcohol, cholecystitis, ectopic pregnancy, gallbladder dysfunction, G.I. perforation, intestinal obstructions, ketoacidosis, lung cancer, mumps, ovarian cancer, pancreatic cancer, pancreatic duct obstruction, parotid gland inflammation.
Pancreatic disease, Renal failure, toxemia of pregnancy.

IV Dextrose, lipemia, citrates, and oxalates may falsely decrease amylase levels. Meds such as aminosalicylic acid, aspirin, azathioprine, corticosteroids, dexamethasone, ethyl alcohol, glucocorticoids, iodine-containing contrast media, loop diuretics, narcotic analgesics, oral contraceptives, and prednisone may increase serum amylase.
Critical Values: Blood: More than three times the upper limit of normal.
Used to evaluate pancreatic function and diagnose pancreatitis.

Lipase is a water-soluble enzyme that breaks down fats and lipids via hydrolysis so they can be absorbed by the intestinal tract. As with amylase, lipase appears in the bloodstream following damage to or disease affecting the pancreatic acinar cells. The common cause for elevated lipase levels is acute pancreatitis. An elevated lipase is an indicator of pancreatitis. It usually it takes approximately 8 – 14 days to return to normal levels and is done with amylase testing as well.

Crohn's disease, cystic fibrosis, diabetes mellitus, cholangitis, hepatic disease, renal failure, acute pancreatitis (acute/chronic), pancreatic pseudocyst, extrahepatic duct obstruction pancreatic cancer, peritonitis, ulcerative colitis.
Ca+ can decrease the lipase levels. Cholinergics, codeine, indomethacin, meperidine, methacholine, and morphine can all increase the serum lipase.
Used to evaluate pancreatic function and diagnose pancreatitis.

Lipid panels are performed to monitor responses to medication and therapy, and also identify a person's risk for cardiac disease. Cholesterol is synthesized by the liver and transported in the circulation in association with lipoproteins which are an accurate predictor of cardiac disease. The low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) have the highest concentration of cholesterol.
Cholesterol is essential to every cell; it is a precursor to adrenal steroids, gonadal steroids, and bile salts and is insoluble in water. Elevated cholesterol, particularly LDL cholesterol, is associated with accelerated atherogenesis. In contrast, raised high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol is protective.

HDL is known as the "good cholesterol" because of its ability to transport cholesterol to the liver to be broken down into metabolites. High-density lipoprotein (HDL) is synthesized in the liver and is one of the five major groups of proteins which enables lipids to be transported in the blood. In healthy people, approximately 30% of cholesterol that is in the blood is carried by HDL from the peripheral tissues to the liver. Your risk for cardiac disease is low with high levels of HDL. The higher your HDL level, the better.
Exercise, alcohol consumption, hyperalphalipoproteinemia, alpha blockers, oral hypoglycemics, hyperbetalipoproteinemia.
MI, stress, renal failure, smoking, metabolic syndromes, beta blockers, diuretics, hepatocellular disease, and hypoproteinemia.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

HDL is known as the "good cholesterol" because of its ability to transport cholesterol to the liver to be broken down into metabolites. High-density lipoprotein (HDL) is synthesized in the liver and is one of the five major groups of proteins which enables lipids to be transported in the blood. In healthy people, approximately 30% of cholesterol that is in the blood is carried by HDL from the peripheral tissues to the liver. Your risk for cardiac disease is low with high levels of HDL. The higher your HDL level, the better.
Exercise, alcohol consumption, hyperalphalipoproteinemia, alpha blockers, oral hypoglycemics, hyperbetalipoproteinemia.
MI, stress, renal failure, smoking, metabolic syndromes, beta blockers, diuretics, hepatocellular disease, and hypoproteinemia.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

LDL is used to evaluate the risk of coronary heart disease. There are five major groups of proteins which include (chylomicrons, the VLDL, IDL, LDL, and HDL). Low-density lipoprotein (HDL) usually synthesized in the liver is one of the five major groups which enables lipids to be transported in the blood. The low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) have the highest concentration of cholesterol. Known as the "bad cholesterol," high levels of LDL can be concerning for cardiovascular disease.

Diabetes mellitus, cholestasis, pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, lipoproteinemia, alcohol consumption, chronic liver disease (e.g., hepatitis or cirrhosis), hepatoma, gammopathies, Cushing syndrome apoprotein CII deficiency.(e.g., hepatitis or cirrhosis), hepatoma. gammopathies, Cushing syndrome apoprotein CII deficiency.
Abetalipoproteinemia, diabetes mellitus, cholestasis, pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia, hypoproteinemia.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

Triglycerides are a glyceride and fat found in the body, (not a type of cholesterol) that are used to estimate VLDL. The body uses these fats for energy and is the primary constituent of vegetable oil and animal fat. High levels can be a sign of cardiovascular disease.

Obesity, kidney disease, alcohol, biliary tract obstruction, cirrhosis, pancreatitis, stress, hypothyroidism, diuretics, anabolic steroids, ovarian tumors, anticonvulsants, estrogens, barbiturates, adrenocortical tumors.
Malabsorption, malnutrition, hyperthyroidism, ascorbic acid, parenchymal liver disease.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

Total cholesterol is used to measure the risk of heart disease by measuring the total amount of cholesterol in the plasma. The sum is determined from the following components (HDL + LDL + VLDL). Approximately 75% of cholesterol is synthesized, and 25% originates from the regular dietary consumption. 50 to 75% of total cholesterol is transported by LDL, and 15 to 40% by HDL. People who have hypercholesterolemia have high risks for cardiac disease. Cholesterol is essential for building cells, and the production of hormones. Triglycerides are not considered Cholesterol.
Cholestasis, pregnancy, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, Cushing's syndrome, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, corticosteroids.
Acute hepatitis, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, liver cancer, hypercholesterolemia, pernicious anemia, hemolytic jaundice.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) is a lipoprotein that is produced in the liver, released into the bloodstream and is considered "bad cholesterol," VLDL transports lipids to different parts of the body and contains the highest amount of triglycerides. Increased levels of VLDL have been linked with the development of plaque deposits on artery walls, which narrow the artery and reduce blood flow.

Diabetes mellitus, cholestasis, pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia, hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome, lipoproteinemia, alcohol consumption, chronic liver disease, hepatitis, cirrhosis, Cushing syndrome apoprotein CII deficiency.(e.g., hepatitis or cirrhosis), hepatoma gammopathies, Cushing syndrome apoprotein CII deficiency.
Abetalipoproteinemia, diabetes mellitus, cholestasis, pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia, hypoproteinemia. (e.g., malabsorption, severe burns), or malnutrition) hypothyroidism, nephrotic syndrome.

Diet, smoking, consumption of alcohol, post-myocardial infarction, elevated in hyperthyroid patients, drugs such as beta blockers, aspirin, estrogens, steroids, and sulfonamides can also alter lipoprotein levels.
Used to evaluate diet, hypercholesterolemia, and treatment for hypercholesterolemia. Evaluate the risk of cardiac disease.

The brain and spinal cord are enclosed by and suspended in a clear, colorless fluid. Patients with acute CNS symptoms often require testing of the fluid. The lumbar puncture test (LP) aka "spinal tap," is a procedure where cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) is collected and examined by inserting a needle into the subarachnoid space of the spinal column. It also may be used to therapeutically administer medications or reduce ICP in patients with conditions such as hydrocephalus. Examination of the fluid includes analysis for blood, protein, glucose and malignant cells.

In normal CSF, the appearance is clear and colorless. Color difference can change with elevated proteins hyperbilirubinemia, hypercarotenemia, or melanoma . However, during SAH or trauma, it can appear red - during infections, the CSF can appear (yellow) and in the presence of WBC can appear cloudy.
Hyperbilirubinemia, hypercarotenemia, melanoma. Cloudy- increased WBC. Red- Presence of RBC, traumatic LP.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

Cell count measures (under the microscope) the number of red blood cells (RBC's) and white blood cells (WBC's) that are present in the cerebral spinal fluid. RBC that is present is suggestive of subarachnoid bleeds, while the presence of WBC greater than five suggests inflammation.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

CSF glucose is used to determine the difference between bacterial or viral meningitis. Compared to viral meningitis, bacterial meningitis will decrease the CSF glucose. When tumors, meningitis or inflammatroy cells are present, the glucose will be decreased. Usually, CSF glucose less than two thirds or 60 % the serum glucose indicates meningitis or neoplasm.
Bacterial infections, meningitis, hypoglycemia, inflammation, subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Dexamethasone and cefotaxime can increase glucose levels. Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme that is found in bacteria which is helpful in diagnosing bacterial meningitis.. LDH present in CSF is an indication of tissue damage, inflammation or infection. Nerve tissue also contains LDH which will be elevated when there is a brain disease. Therefore, a condition directly affecting the brain or spinal cord (e.g., stroke) is directly linked with elevated LDH levels.
Bacterial meningitis, central nervous system leukemia, stroke.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

Lactic acid is a by-product of anaerobic respiration, during glycolysis when there is a marked decrease of oxygen, lactic acid levels rise because of oxygen not being capable of breaking down glucose in the CSF. Thus, lactate in the cerebral spinal fluid measures whether brain tissues or being oxygen deprived. CSF lactic acid is increased in both bacterial and fungal meningitis but not in viral meningitis.
Anaerobic respiration in the brain, bacterial meningitis, fungal meningitis.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

The opening pressures (using a sterile manometer) are taken during the LP in the area of L3 – L4 in the subarachnoid space. A manometer is used to measure the opening pressures of the CSF. Because the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain directly communicates to the subarachnoid space of the spinal cord, measurements are particularly relevant to help diagnose increases in ICP and different types of meningitis. Further, increases in ICP could be related venous obstructions since the cranial venous sinuses are connected to the SVC and jugular veins.

Bacterial meningitis, brain abscess, fungal infections, spinal tumors, subdural empyema, encephalitis tuberculosis, Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (IIH), intracranial vasculitis, cerebral edema, subarachnoid hemorrhage.
Leaking from the lumbar puncture, spinal epidural abscess, spontaneous CSF leak, trauma, fungal infection.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

Usually, protein is not found in the cerebrospinal fluid because they are large molecules and are unable to pass through the blood brain barrier. Protein is one of the most sensitive indicators within the Central Nervous System. Protein levels in the cerebrospinal fluid can also be used to differentiate between bacterial and viral meningitis as well. In bacterial infections (such as bacterial meningitis, and TB meningitis) the protein will be substantially elevated.
This is because these diseases can alter the permeability of the blood-brain barrier allowing for the protein to leak into the cerebral spinal fluid. However, there may be mild elevations with viral meningitis as well. Protein levels will also be raised in different neurological disorders, inflammation processes, or interruption of the blood-brain barrier.
Intracranial hemorrhage (ICH), multiple sclerosis, encephalitis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, inflammatory conditions, falsely positive during a traumatic tap.
Repeated lumbar punctures, chronic leaking, malignancies.

Dexamethasone and cefotaxime can decrease protein levels. Interferon B may increase protein levels. Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

There should be absolutely no red blood cells found in the CSF. The CSF should be clear, colorless and without any cells. Nevertheless, the presence of blood cells may indicate a traumatic tap or a subarachnoid bleed. Xanthochromia could suggest hemorrhaging.

Traumatic spinal tap. Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

When the WBC's are greater than 8 WBC/uL, in the presence of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (neutrophils) is suggestive of bacterial meningitis or cerebral abscess. When mononuclear leukocytes are present, viral or tubercular meningitis or encephalitis is presumed. Leukemia or other primary or metastatic malignant tumors may also cause elevated WBCs. Grossly increased white blood cells that are found in the CSF will produce a cloudy appearance during a lumbar puncture.
Bacterial meningitis, fungal meningitis, TB meningitis.

Caution in patients with degenerative joint disease or coagulation defects and in patients who are uncooperative during the procedure. Extreme caution in patients with increased ICP-rapid removal of CSF can result in herniation.

Assists patients with subarachnoid hemorrhages vs. ICH, viral vs. bacterial meningitis, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, CNS infections, metastatic brain cancer and monitor CSF due to tumors, hemorrhaging or edema.

The Thyroid Function Test is used to test the function of the thyroid gland. The two major hormones produced by the thyroid gland are T3 and T4. Deficiencies in these hormones may cause weight gain, lack of energy (Hypothyroidism). Overproduction may cause weight loss, anxiety, tremors (Hyperthyroidism).

Triiodothyronine (T3) is the primary active form of the thyroid hormone which is bound to the protein thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). Produced by the thyroid gland, and activated by TSH, T3 affects the majority of every physiological process in the body including metabolism, temperature regulation, heart rate, and development.
Only a relatively small portion of T3 that circulates in the blood comes from the thyroid. The rest is T4. T3 can be used in the evaluation of hyperthyroidism, but other than that has no clinical value.

Hyperthyroidism, increased thyroid binding globulin (TBG), thyrotoxicosis, amiodarone, estrogens, tamoxifen, thyroxine, estrogen therapy, Graves disease, oral contraceptives, pregnancy, liver disease.
Anabolic steroids, carbamazepine, decreased thyroid – binding globulin (TBG), malnutrition, lithium, theophylline, glucocorticoids, cirrhosis, Cushing's syndrome, myxedema, and hypothyroidism.
Pregnancy, estrogen, methadone, and contraceptives can all increase T3 levels. Medications such as steroids, androgens, propanolol, salicylates at high doses, phenytoin can decrease T3 levels.
Assists patients with triiodothyronine toxicosis. Also, used to test for hyperthyroidism in patients with low TSH and normal thyroxine levels.

Secreted by the thyroid gland, thyroid hormones regulate numerous metabolic and developmental activities in the body. Two of the four hormones secreted by the thyroid gland is thyroxine, which contains four atoms of iodine which is (T4).
T4 is the primary hormone secreted by the thyroid gland. T4 is biologically active; thus thyroxine can be measured as free thyroxine.
T4 plays a role affecting the majority of every physiological process in the body including metabolism, temperature regulation, heart rate, and development. Thyroxine is essential for controlling lipid, carbohydrate and protein metabolism.

Acute/chronic thyroiditis, amiodarone, beta blockers, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, germ cell tumors, pregnancy, thyroid adenoma, hepatitis, thyroid cancer, Graves disease, hyperthyroidism, iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.
Hypothyroidism, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, malnutrition, iodine insufficiency, thyroid agenesis, myxedema, pituitary insufficiency, hypothalamic failure.

Neonates tend to have higher T4 levels. Radioisotopes can alter levels. Pregnancy, exacerbates T4. Estrogens, contraceptives, heroin, and methadone can all increase T4 levels. Medications such as steroids, androgens, lithium, propranolol, and anti-thyroid drugs can decrease T4 levels.
Used to evaluate thyroid dysfunction and to detect primary hypo/hyperthyroidism.

Secreted by the thyroid gland, thyroid hormones regulate numerous metabolic and developmental activities in the body. Two of the four hormones secreted by the thyroid gland or thyroxine, which contain for atoms of iodine which is (T4). T4 is the primary hormone secreted by the thyroid gland. T4 is biologically active thus thyroxine can be measured as free thyroxine.
T4 plays a role affecting the majority of every physiological process in the body including metabolism, temperature regulation, heart rate, and development. Thyroxine is essential for controlling lipid, carbohydrate and protein metabolism.

Acute/chronic thyroiditis, amiodarone, beta blockers, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, germ cell tumors, pregnancy, thyroid adenoma, hepatitis, thyroid cancer, Graves disease, hyperthyroidism, iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.
Hypothyroidism, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, malnutrition, iodine insufficiency, thyroid agenesis, myxedema, pituitary insufficiency, hypothalamic failure.

Neonates tend to have higher T4 levels. Radioisotopes can alter levels. Pregnancy, exactness T4. Estrogens, contraceptives, heroin, and methadone can all increase T4 levels. Medications such as steroids, androgens, lithium, propranolol, and anti-thyroid drugs can decrease T4 levels.
Used to evaluate thyroid dysfunction and to detect primary hypo/hyperthyroidism.

Two of the four hormones secreted by the thyroid gland or thyroxine, which contain for atoms of iodine which is (T4). T4 is the primary hormone secreted by the thyroid gland. T4 is biologically active thus thyroxine can be measured as free thyroxine.
T4 plays a role affecting the majority of every physiological process in the body including metabolism, temperature regulation, heart rate, and development. Thyroxine is essential for controlling lipid, carbohydrate and protein metabolism.

Acute/chronic thyroiditis, amiodarone, beta blockers, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, germ cell tumors, pregnancy, thyroid adenoma, hepatitis, thyroid cancer, Graves disease, hyperthyroidism, iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.
Hypothyroidism, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, malnutrition, iodine insufficiency, thyroid agenesis, myxedema, pituitary insufficiency, hypothalamic failure.

Neonates tend to have higher T4 levels. Radioisotopes can alter levels. Pregnancy, exactness T4. Estrogens, contraceptives, heroin, and methadone can all increase T4 levels. Medications such as steroids, androgens, lithium, propranolol, and anti-thyroid drugs can decrease T4 levels.
Used to evaluate thyroid dysfunction and to detect primary hypo/hyperthyroidism.
Thyroxine Binding Globulin is a special carrier protein that thyroxine is bound to in the blood.
Hepatitis, an excess of Hereditary TBG, pregnancy, thyroid carcinoma, estrogens.
Acromegaly, hereditary TBG deficiency, hypoalbuminemia, anabolic steroids, corticosteroids, stress, testosterone producing tumors.

Medications can also affect TBG levels. Estrogens, methadone, oral contraceptives, and tamoxifen can increase TBG. Androgens, anabolic steroids, danazol, phenytoin, propranolol, and steroids can decrease the TBG.

Used to evaluate thyroid dysfunction and to detect primary hypo/hyperthyroidism. Predict TRH-stimulated TSH response. Confirm TSH suppression in thyroid cancer patients treated with thyroxine therapy.

When the thyroid gland is not functioning well, there may be high or low levels of TSH present in the blood. The Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) is a peptide hormone which is released by the anterior pituitary gland that acts to encourage the thyroid gland to synthesize T3 and T4. In primary hypothyroidism, TSH levels will be increased. Conversely, in primary hyperthyroidism, TSH levels will be decreased.
Primary hypothyroidism, thyroid agenesis, pituitary tumor, thyroiditis.
Acute illnesses, Secondary hypothyroidism, pituitary, hyperthyroidism, subclinical hyperthyroidism, dopamine, excessive corticosteroids.

Radioisotopes, conditions that decrease TSH levels. Antithyroid medications, lithium, potassium iodide, and TSH injection can increase the TSH. Conversely, dopamine, heparin, steroids, and T3 can decrease the TSH.

Used to evaluate thyroid dysfunction and to detect primary hypo/hyperthyroidism. Predict TRH-stimulated TSH response. Confirm TSH suppression in thyroid cancer patients treated with thyroxine therapy.
Urine is a waste product that is made by the kidneys. This test measures the urine chemically, physically, and microscopically. Various compounds that pass through the urine are carefully evaluated.

Bilirubin originally is acquired from the metabolism of hemoglobin. Typically, it's excreted via the bile ducts into the bowels. In the bowels, bacteria transform bilirubin into urobilinogen. Conjugated (direct) bilirubin is water soluble and is excreted in the urine, and typically, only trace amounts can be detected in urine. Unconjugated bilirubin caused by prehepatic jaundice will not be excreted in the urine because it is not water soluble.
High urinary bilirubin occurs in patients with obstructive jaundice or jaundice due to hepatocellular disease or injury. However, urine bilirubin is nearly indifferent to detecting liver diseases.
Positive or trace values suggest post-hepatic biliary obstruction or hepatocellular disease.

False positive tests may occur if urine is contaminated with stool, or if the patient is taking drugs which cause red coloration of urine. False negative tests may occur after prolonged storage, exposure to light, or if patient has taken large amounts of ascorbic acid.

In a normal functioning kidney, glucose is normally reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. If a patient is hyperglycemic then residual glucose will not be absorbed and should be concerning for diabetes mellitus. When the serum glucose rises above 200 mg/dL, filtered glucose will exceed the capacity for tubular reabsorption and glucose will be dumped into the urine.
Assists patients with DKA management of diabetes mellitus and proximal tubule function.

Ketones are a by-product of fatty acid breakdown in the liver not typically found in the body. Ketones are three water-soluble compounds (acetone, acetoacetate, & beta-hydroxybutyrate ) that are used as energy in the heart and the brain. When the body does not produce enough sugar carbohydrates, there will be an increasing amount of ketones in the body. Ketone bodies in the urine indicate that cellular metabolism is dependent upon fatty acids rather than glucose for energy. Patients who are hyperglycemic and have poorly controlled diabetes will produce ketones from fatty acid catabolism. These ketones subsequently spill into the urine when they reach high levels.
Alcoholic ketoacidosis, anorexia, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), fasting, isopropyl alcohol intoxication, hyperthyroidism, low-carb diet, prolonged hypoglycemia, malnutrition, starvation.
Diets such as carbohydrate-free, high-protein, high-fat may cause ketonuria. False-positive results from meds such as isoniazid, isopropanol, levodopa, and paraldehyde.
Assists patients with DKA and unexplained increases in the anion gap.

Leukocyte Esterase is used to detect leukocyte esterase in the urine. This is an enzyme that is present in most white blood cells (WBC). This test is most often combined with urine nitrite testing. Positive Leukocyte Esterase in the urine may be highly suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI) or kidney inflammation.
Cystitis, pyelonephritis, urethritis, urinary tract infection.
Vaginal secretions such as heavy menstrual discharge, Trichomonas infection, parasites that contain WBC's, high levels of protein or ascorbic acid may render false-negative results.
Assists patients with possible UTI's, fluid balance, renal function and the response to medication therapy and routine screening.

Many bacteria produce an enzyme called reductase that reduces nitrates to nitrites. Urine nitrites are usually not found in the urine; however, if they are found in the urine, similar to leukocyte esterase, it is highly indicative of a urinary tract infection (UTI) - specifically bacteriuria with Gram-negative organisms most commonly Escherichia Coli (E. coli) which convert nitrate to nitrite. Positive testing should result in a subsequent urine culture.
Bacteria that don't contain reductase. Urine retained in the bladder for more than 4 hours. The absence of dietary nitrates.
Assists patients with possible UTI's, fluid balance, renal function and the response to medication therapy and routine screening.

The kidneys play a significant part in regulating acid-base balance in the body. Therefore acidic / basic foods ingested throughout the day, medications and renal tubular function can directly affect the pH of the urine.
Similarly, substances that are dissolved in the urine can form crystals. These crystals develop into kidney stones or "calculi." These calculi can be modified by diet and medications. Urine pH < 6.0 can help reduce the ability of renal calculi formation. Conversely, a pH > 6.0 can reduce the incidence of uric acid stones.
Gastric suctioning, low-carb diet, vegetarian diet, respiratory alkalosis, renal tubular acidosis, systemic acidosis/ alkalosis, sodium bicarbonate, metabolic alkalosis, UTI, vomiting.
DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis), diarrhea, fever, fasting, high-protein diet, metabolic acidosis, starvation, respiratory acidosis, pyrexia, renal calculi, UTI.

An uncovered specimen will become alkaline because carbon dioxide vaporizes from the urine. Dietary factors such as dairy, fruits, and vegetables. Meds that can increase urine pH are acetazolamide, bicarbonate antacids, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. Meds that can decrease urine pH include ammonium chloride, chlorothiazide.

Monitoring the effectiveness of alkalinization or acidification of urine for specific conditions such as the treatment of uric acid nephrolithiasis. Also, evaluate for metabolic acidosis, and crystalluria.

Protein found in urine is usually in small excess. This is why protein is considered a sensitive indicator of renal and glomerular function. The kidneys do an exceptional job at filtering protein, nevertheless, when protein levels exceed these values it's concerning for renal dysfunction.
Proteinuria (usually albumin) is probably the most important indicator of renal disease. Protein levels between 100 and 300 mg/dL maybe from microalbuminuria, which usually stems from diabetes, is an early sign of kidney disease. Higher levels (over 300 mg/dL) indicate serious renal dysfunction. In pregnancy, the presence of urine protein is routinely checked. Protein present in pregnancy is an indicator of preeclampsia.

Aminoglycosides, aspirin, contrast dye, diabetes mellitus, malignant hypertension, glomerulonephritis, Goodpasture syndrome, hypertension, kidney infection, multiple myeloma, Nephrotic Syndrome's, polycystic diseases, preeclampsia, salicylates, SLE, bladder tumors.

Meds such as acetazolamide, aminoglycosides, amphotericin B, cephalosporins, lithium, methicillin, nafcillin, nephrotoxic drugs, oxacillin, penicillin G, salicylates, sulfonamides, tolbutamide, and vancomycin can cause increased protein levels.
Used to evaluate kidney disease and to rule out monoclonal gammopathy.

Specific gravity is defined as the weight of the urine when compared to the density of water. When there are additional particles, glucose or proteins present in the urine, then the urine is heavier thus, increasing the specific gravity. A high specific gravity indicates concentrated urine; a low specific gravity suggests dilute urine.
Dehydration, fasting, glycosuria, proteinuria, contrast dye.
Over hydration, excessive water intake, Diabetes insipidus
Radiographic dyes, dextran, mannitol, and sucrose can increase specific gravity.
Used to evaluate the kidney's ability to concentrate urine.

The urine osmolality is used to evaluate kidney function and its ability to excrete salts such as Na+, K+, and Urea. The exceptional ability of the kidney to equally maintain water balance and tonicity of ECF is reflected by the urine osmolality.
More precise than the specific gravity (SG), the osmolarity measures the number of dissolved particles in a given solution. Urine osmolality can be measured over a wide range of different urine concentrations, more than specific gravity and with higher accuracy.
SIADH , acidosis, shock, cirrhosis, CHF, Addison's disease, shock.
DI, hypercalcemia, ATN, hypokalemia, pyelonephritis, aldosteronism.
Used to evaluate the kidney's ability to concentrate and dilute urine.
